posts.title: In Europe, wind and solar overtake fossil fuels
posts.author: speckx
posts.title_cn: 在欧洲，风能和太阳能超越化石燃料
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕欧洲风能与太阳能发电量超越化石燃料的新闻展开。核心争议点在于数据的解读方式：有用户指出报道中的“发电量”与“总能源消耗”存在差异，因为电力仅占欧洲总能源消耗的一部分，交通、供暖等领域仍依赖化石燃料。同时，部分用户对标题的准确性提出质疑，认为过往类似报道常存在限定条件（如仅对比煤炭或单日数据）。讨论中提到，尽管存在统计口径的争议，多数用户仍认可可再生能源发展的积极趋势，特别是太阳能和风能成本下降带来的竞争力。也有用户推荐相关分析，预测可再生能源将按“S曲线”快速取代传统能源。此外，有评论提及美国政策对风电发展的影响，以及电池技术提升对太阳能应用的推动作用。整体上，社区在肯定可再生能源进展的同时，强调需区分电力与整体能源结构的变化。

comments.author: kokey
comments.content: Every time, over the years, that there has been some kind of headline saying renewables have overtaken fossil fuels, when you look at it a bit more closely there is always a big 'but'.   For example, it was compared to coal (not taking into account electricity from gas), or it was for one day, or it was a percentage of new installations, or it excludes winter, includes nuclear etc.This time, however, it looks like it's actually true and that's just for wind and solar.   This is incredible, and done through slowly compounding gains that didn't cause massive economic hardships along the way.
comments.content_cn: 多年来，每当有头条新闻宣称可再生能源已超越化石燃料时，仔细审视后总会发现一个巨大的“但是”。例如，可能是与煤炭相比（未计入天然气发电），或仅指某一天的数据，或是新增装机容量的比例，又或是排除冬季、包含核电等情况。然而这一次，仅就风能和太阳能而言，情况似乎确实如此。这令人难以置信，而且是通过缓慢累积的成果实现的，过程中并未造成大规模的经济困境。

comments.author: softwaredoug
comments.content: It used to be the big worry among climate activists that you'd never get every country organize and move in one direction. Like you'd need some global body to clean everything up.That's very fragile.Luckily, we're moving to a world where a disjoint, self-interested response can be an advantage. Countries decide, for their own selfish reasons, to adopt green energy. For energy independence, affordability, clean air, etc.So when one country politically rotates out for dumb reasons, other countries pick up the slack and make a bit of progress.
comments.content_cn: 过去气候活动家们最担心的是各国永远无法协调一致、朝同一个方向努力。就像需要一个全球性机构来统筹一切，这种模式非常脆弱。幸运的是，我们正走向一个分散化、基于自身利益采取行动反而能成为优势的世界。各国出于自身利益考量——例如能源独立、成本可控、空气清洁等原因——主动选择发展绿色能源。因此，当某个国家因政治短视而退出时，其他国家会填补空缺并推动进程继续前进。

comments.author: usrnm
comments.content: The article uses the words "more power" and "overtaking fossil fuels", but the graph is actually about electricity generation. They are not the same thing, at least, in my head, because not all energy consumed in Europe comes in the form of electricity. If I heat my home with natural gas and drive an ICE car, this is me using fossil fuels in a way that has nothing to do with electricity and it won't be reflected in that graph. This is an important stepping stone, but it is not "solar and wind overtaking fossil fuels in Europe"
comments.content_cn: 文章使用了“更多能源”和“超越化石燃料”这样的表述，但图表实际上讨论的是发电量。这两者并不完全等同，至少在我看来如此，因为欧洲消耗的能源并非全部以电力形式存在。如果我使用天然气取暖并驾驶燃油车，这意味着我消耗化石燃料的方式与电力无关，这部分数据不会体现在图表中。这是一个重要的进展，但并不能称之为“太阳能和风能在欧洲已超越化石燃料”。

comments.author: owenversteeg
comments.content: The only asterisk this time is that this is electricity, not energy. Still impressive, but electricity is only 22% of total energy use, so they are at about 12% of the total for the EU and 7.8% for Europe.For that, you want this graph: https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/energy-consumption-by-sou...Fun to play around with, you can also change the selection to view the world, US, China, individual EU countries etc.You can see that this the gain in renewables in the EU has been mainly at the expense of coal (down >50% as a share of total energy use in 10 years), gas (down 4%), and nuclear (down 20%.) Oil use as a share of the total is up by 5%.
comments.content_cn: 这次唯一的附加说明是，这里指的是电力而非能源总量。数据依然令人印象深刻，但电力仅占能源总消耗的22%，因此欧盟的可再生能源约占其能源总量的12%，欧洲整体则为7.8%。关于这一点，可以参考这张图表：https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/energy-consumption-by-sou... 图表交互性很强，你可以切换选择查看全球、美国、中国、欧盟各国等数据。从图中可见，欧盟可再生能源的增长主要替代了煤炭（十年间在能源总消耗占比下降超50%）、天然气（下降4%）和核能（下降20%）。石油消耗占比则上升了5%。

comments.author: when_creaks
comments.content: Encouraging. However, it isn't clear from the article at first glance (or the deeper analysis being referenced) how electricity consumption by power source is changing.In other words, as an example, a 10% increase in solar power generation does not necessarily mean that there was a 10% increase in electricity consumption where that electricity was generated via solar.i.e. It is entirely possible for a growing solar fleet to generate more power during the middle of the day than previously, and simultaneously for not all of that increased power to be used / usable.
comments.content_cn: 令人鼓舞。然而，文章乍看之下（或所引用的深入分析）并未明确说明不同电源的电力消耗情况如何变化。换言之，举例来说，太阳能发电量增长10%并不一定意味着通过太阳能产生的电力消耗也增长了10%。也就是说，完全有可能出现这样的情况：日益壮大的太阳能发电系统在中午时段产生的电力比以前更多，但与此同时，并非所有增加的电力都能被使用或得到有效利用。

comments.content_cn: 如果你对这个话题感兴趣，我强烈推荐托尼·塞巴的分析。他认为，由于太阳能和风能现在是成本最低的新型发电方式，它们正处在一条势不可挡的指数型“S曲线”上，将在2030年前使煤炭、天然气和核能过时。你可以在YouTube上搜索他的视频，例如这个：https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Kj96nxtHdTU

comments.author: p0pularopinion
comments.content: I'm curious as to how this will shift once the shift towards more electrification continues. Once demand shifts in favor of the electrified alternatives, electricity demand is continuing to raise (although not as steep as the drop in demand for the fossil fuels will be). Particularly in heating, where peak demand is in times with very little solar generation, it seems like this will be challenging.While the prices of energy storage have come down significantly and are projected to continue to drop, there is still a noteable lack of cost effective long term storage solutions.
comments.content_cn: 我很好奇随着电气化进程的持续推进，这种情况将如何转变。这里讨论的仅是发电量，而非总能耗。目前，在供暖或驾驶汽车等高能耗领域，化石燃料仍比电力替代方案更为普遍。一旦需求转向电气化替代方案，电力需求将持续增长（尽管增速不会像化石燃料需求下降那样剧烈）。特别是在供暖方面，其需求高峰往往出现在太阳能发电极少的时段，这似乎将带来挑战。虽然储能成本已显著下降且预计将持续降低，但目前仍明显缺乏具有成本效益的长期储能解决方案。

comments.author: pranavj
comments.content: The most underreported part of this story is the battery piece at the end. Batteries are beginning to displace natural gas in evening peak hours - that's the exact window where solar critics have long argued renewables fall short. If this trend accelerates (and battery prices are dropping faster than most models predicted), the "intermittency problem" starts looking more like a solvable engineering challenge than a fundamental barrier.The next milestone to watch: when battery-backed solar becomes cheaper than gas peakers for evening demand across most of Europe. We might be closer than people think.
comments.content_cn: 这个故事中最未被充分报道的部分是结尾关于电池的内容。电池正开始在晚间用电高峰时段取代天然气——这正是太阳能批评者长期以来认为可再生能源存在不足的时段。如果这一趋势加速发展（而且电池价格的下降速度比大多数模型预测的更快），那么"间歇性问题"看起来更像是一个可以解决的工程挑战，而非根本性障碍。下一个值得关注的里程碑是：当配备电池的太阳能系统在满足欧洲大部分地区晚间用电需求时，其成本低于天然气调峰电厂。我们可能比人们想象的更接近这一目标。

comments.content_cn: 观察得很准。在大多数欧盟国家，电力约占最终能源消耗的20-25%。真正的考验在于，廉价的可再生电力能否足够快地将供暖（热泵）和交通（电动汽车）纳入电网。令人鼓舞的迹象是，这两方面都在推进——多个欧盟国家的热泵销量激增，电动汽车的普及速度也远超五年前的大多数预测。但你说得对，在总能源消耗中“超越化石燃料”仍需数年时间。

comments.author: eigenspace
comments.content: It can be rather misleading to to talk about renewable energy generation versus total energy usage.Most uses of fossil fuels are very inefficient. For instance, when you step on the accelerator in your car, only around 30% of the energy in the fuel you use actually is being used to propel you forward. The majority of the energy is wasted as heat. In a power plant that's more like 70% being captured and going towards the goal (electricity generation).Another large quantity of energy-usage is heating, and electrical heat-pumps can be around 3-5x more energy efficient at heating an enclosed space than combustion or resistive heating.So while things like heating an transportation use a very large amount of energy, conquering them with renewables actually won't require that Europe installs 10x or whatever more wind and solar, since electrification also brings significant new efficiencies.______If you want to compare renewables against the amount of fossil fuels being burnt, then it'd be a lot more representative if you calculate the amount of wind energy impacting a wind turbine blade, or the amount of energy in solar radiation incident on a solar panel. That's an easy way to inflate the renewable numbers by ~5x or whatever
comments.content_cn:
将可再生能源发电量与总能源消耗量进行对比可能会产生相当大的误导性。化石燃料的多数应用方式效率极低。例如，当你踩下汽车油门时，所用燃料中仅有约30%的能量真正用于推动车辆前进，大部分能量都以热能形式浪费了。而在发电厂中，约有70%的能量能被捕获并用于发电目标。

另一大能源消耗领域是供暖，而电热泵在密闭空间供暖方面的能效比燃烧加热或电阻加热高出约3-5倍。因此，虽然供暖和交通等领域消耗着巨量能源，但用可再生能源攻克这些领域实际上并不需要欧洲安装十倍或任意倍数的风电和光伏设备，因为电气化转型本身就能带来显著的能效提升。

若要将可再生能源与化石燃料燃烧量进行对比，更合理的做法是计算作用在风力涡轮机叶片上的风能总量，或是照射在太阳能电池板上的太阳辐射能量。这种计算方式能轻易将可再生能源数据夸大五倍乃至更多。

comments.author: eigenspace
comments.content: What you're talking about is commonly called "curtailment", where power generators like wind and solar can be told to basically stop feeding into the grid, effectively wasting their energy.From what I recall, curtailment of wind and solar at least in Germany amounts to about 3% wasted energy from those sources, so no, it's not a very significant worry. These renewable sources really are displacing fossil fuels.A big part of this story is batteries. Especially during the summer, the wholesale electricity price in Germany can swing daily from -10 to +10 cents per kWh during the mid-day, up to 150+ cents per kWh at night, due to supply-and-demand.This gradient in prices creates a huge incentive for people to build batteries that buy up cheap electricity during the day (sometimes literally getting paid to do so), so that they can sell it back later on in the day when prices rise. This incentive helps make sure energy does not get wasted, it encourages more batteries to be installed, and it encourages businesses to shift the their energy usage to times of the day that align with high renewable output.
comments.content_cn:
你提到的现象通常被称为"弃电"，即风力和太阳能发电站可能被要求停止向电网供电，实际上造成能源浪费。据我所知，德国风电和太阳能的弃电率约为3%，因此这确实不是需要特别担忧的问题。这些可再生能源确实在替代化石燃料。

电池储能是其中的关键因素。特别是在夏季，德国电力批发价格每日波动剧烈：午间时段每千瓦时可能在负10欧分到正10欧分之间浮动，而夜间价格可能飙升至每千瓦时150欧分以上，这主要受供需关系影响。

这种价格差形成了强大的市场激励：人们建造储能电池在白天低价购电（有时甚至能获得补贴），待电价上涨时再售出。这种机制不仅有效减少了能源浪费，还促进了储能设施的扩建，同时激励企业将用电时段调整至可再生能源发电高峰期。

comments.content: > Particularly in heating, where peak demand is in times with very little solar generation, it seems like this will be challenging.Heating is actually likely to be one of the easier questions here, because heat is just fundamentally an easier problem to tackle than most other intensive uses of energy in the modern world.1. Solar isn't the only incredibly cheap form of intermittant renwewable energy production. Wind is also great, tends to support local manufacturing economies more than solar, and is anti-correlated with peak-sunshine. The wind tends to blow hardest in the winter and around sunset.2. Heatpumps can pretty comfortably achieve 300+% coefficients of performance, meaning that for every joule of energy you put into a heatpump, you'll get 3+ joules of heat pumped into your home, office, or city-scale heat thermos3. Heat energy storage is cheap compared to batteries. You just store large quantities of water or sand and heat it up with a resistor or a heat pump. The scaling of surface area versus volume  ensures that the bigger you make the heat-battery, the less energy you'll lose from it over time (percentage wise).4. Heat is a waste product from many other forms of energy usage, and can be harnessed. For instance, gas peaker plants aren't going away any time soon, and cities which aren't harnessing the waste heat from those peaker plants and using it in a district heating system are wasting both money and carbon.Just a couple kilometers from my home for instance is a gas power plant that stores waste heat in giant thermoses, and pumps hot water to my building to to be used for heating. They currently have the largest heat pump in europe under construction on the same site intended to supplement the gas plant, both to take up slack from the fact that it'll be running less often, and to expand the service to yet more households.

comments.author: MakersF
comments.content:
It's unfair you're being down voted, you're right.
I used to think that we could get by with just solar wind and batteries, but then after collaborating with people on an ideal energy mix the numbers were obvious: there is a (small) fraction that cannot be covered.
Not with storage (the discharge cycles are so few that the cost is prohibitive. How can a battery pay for itself with 10-20 discharges a year? And this applies to any kind of battery that needs to be built, including hydro).
Likely there will need to be some baseload nuclear (which then increases average prices, since to make it economical you need to buy all the electricity it produces, and so it partially displaces renewables). The alternative is overbuilding solar+wind+battery something like 5/8 times the average need. Maybe if the prices drop enough that could be feasible..
The big win would be if there is some way to get predictable power at a lower cost than nuclear (e.g. tidal), which could be used to smooth the troughts, or alternatively a low capex but potentially high opex solution which is turned on only when needed (gas is an option, but not co2 free. And sizing the power needed is not super cheap, although now it's not a problem since we have enough gas capacity which is going to be displaced, so it won't be needed to be built)

posts.title: GPTZero finds 100 new hallucinations in NeurIPS 2025 accepted papers
posts.author: segmenta
posts.title_cn: GPTZero在NeurIPS 2025录用论文中发现100处新幻觉
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕GPTZero在NeurIPS 2025录用论文中发现100处AI生成幻觉的问题展开。核心争议在于学术界对使用LLM生成参考文献的态度及此类问题的严重性。

有人认为，部分作者直接使用ChatGPT生成文献引用却未核实，导致出现虚构作者或错误来源，这严重违背学术诚信。也有用户指出，NeurIPS领导层认为幻觉参考文献不一定构成拒稿理由，引发对会议评审标准的质疑。讨论中提到，此类现象可能因媒体夸大报道而引发过度恐慌，实际比例需结合论文总数（4841篇）理性看待。

用户普遍认同，文献综述本应与前人研究对话，而用LLM伪造引用破坏了学术研究的根基。分歧在于：一方强调必须严厉惩罚此类行为，另一方则呼吁关注更广泛的学术不端历史（如LLM普及前的捏造来源现象）。另有观点质疑该报告实为GPTZero的软性广告。

This paper was published at ICLR 2024." I.e., for one cited paper, the author list was off and the venue was wrong. And this citation was mentioned in the background section of the paper, and not fundamental to the validity of the paper. comments.author: godelski
comments.content: Funding is definitely a problem, but frankly reproduction is common. If you build off someone else's work (as is the norm) you need to reproduce first.But without repetition being impactful to your career and the pressure to quickly and constantly push new work, a failure to reproduce is generally considered a reason to move on and tackle a different domain. It takes longer to trace the failure and the bar is higher to counter an existing work. It's much more likely you've made a subtle mistake. It's much more likely the other work had a subtle success. It's much more likely the other work simply wasn't written such that a work could be sufficiently reproduced.I speak from experience too. I still remember in grad school I was failing to reproduce a work that was the main competitor to the work I had done (I needed to create comparisons). I emailed the author and got no response. Luckily my advisor knew the author's advisor and we got a meeting set up and I got the code. It didn't do what was claimed in the paper and the code structure wasn't what was described either. The result? My work didn't get published and we moved on. The other work was from a top 10 school and the choice was to burn a bridge and put a black mark on my reputation (from someone with far more merit and prestige) or move on.That type of thing won't change in a reproduction system but needs an open system and open reproduction system as well. Mistakes are common and we shouldn't punish them. The only way to solve these issues is openness
comments.content_cn:
资金确实是个问题，但坦率地说，可复现性差的现象很普遍。如果你基于他人的成果开展研究（这是常态），首先就需要进行复现。但由于复现工作对职业生涯影响有限，加上快速持续产出新成果的压力，复现失败通常会被视为转向其他研究领域的理由。追溯失败原因耗时更长，反驳现有研究成果的门槛也更高。更可能的情况是你犯了细微的错误，或是他人的研究存在不易察觉的成功之处，又或是原研究成果的表述方式本身就难以被充分复现。

我也有亲身经历。至今记得研究生时期，我曾无法复现一项与我研究成果直接竞争的工作（我需要进行对比分析）。邮件联系作者未获回复，所幸我的导师认识对方导师，通过安排会面我最终拿到了代码。但该代码既未实现论文宣称的功能，其结构也与描述不符。结果呢？我的研究未能发表，我们选择了转向。那项成果来自顶尖名校，当时要么选择公开质疑（这等同于与声望更高的学者决裂并给自己的声誉抹黑），要么选择放弃。

这类问题不会因建立复现体系而改变，我们更需要开放的研究体系和开放的复现机制。错误在所难免，我们不应因此惩罚研究者。唯一的解决途径是……

comments.author: StableAlkyne
comments.content: > I'd love to see future reporting that instead of saying "Research finds amazing chemical x which does y" you see "Researcher reproduces amazing results for chemical x which does y. First discovered by z".Most people (that I talk to, at least) in science agree that there's a reproducibility crisis. The challenge is there really isn't a good way to incentivize that work.Fundamentally (unless you're independent wealthy and funding your own work), you have to measure productivity somehow, whether you're at a university, government lab, or the private sector. That turns out to be very hard to do.If you measure raw number of papers (more common in developing countries and low-tier universities), you incentivize a flood of junk. Some of it is good, but there is such a tidal wave of shit that most people write off your work as a heuristic based on the other people in your cohort.So, instead it's more common to try to incorporate how "good" a paper is, to reward people with a high quantity of "good" papers. That's quantifying something subjective though, so you might try to use something like citation count as a proxy: if a work is impactful, usually it gets cited a lot. Eventually you may arrive at something like the H-index, which is defined as "The highest number H you can pick, where H is the number of papers you have written with H citations." Now, the trouble with this method is people won't want to "waste" their time on incremental work.And that's the struggle here; even if we funded and rewarded people for reproducing results, they will always be bumping up the citation count of the original discoverer. But it's worse than that, because literally nobody is going to cite your work. In 10 years, they just see the original paper, a few citing works reproducing it, and to save time they'll just cite the original paper only.There's clearly a problem with how we incentivize scientific work. And clearly we want to be in a world where people test reproducibility. However, it's very very hard to get there when one's prestige and livelihood is directly tied to discovery rather than reproducibility.

从根本上说（除非你资金独立并能自主资助研究），无论是在大学、政府实验室还是私营部门，都必须通过某种方式衡量产出效率。事实证明这非常困难。

如果单纯以论文数量为标准（这在发展中国家和普通高校更为常见），就会催生大量低质量论文。虽然其中也有优秀成果，但垃圾论文如潮水般涌来，导致大多数人会基于你所在群体的整体表现，直接对你的工作价值进行经验性判断。

因此更常见的做法是尝试评估论文的"质量"，奖励那些产出大量"优质"论文的研究者。但这涉及量化主观判断，于是人们可能采用引用次数作为替代指标：如果一项研究具有影响力，通常会被频繁引用。最终可能会采用H指数这样的指标，其定义为"你所能选取的最大数值H，使得你至少有H篇论文每篇被引用至少H次"。但这种方法的问题在于，研究者不愿在渐进性研究上"浪费"时间。

这就是当前困境所在：即使我们……

posts.title: Your brain on ChatGPT: Accumulation of cognitive debt when using an AI assistant
posts.author: misswaterfairy
posts.title_cn: 你的大脑与ChatGPT：使用AI助手时的认知债务累积
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕使用ChatGPT等AI助手可能导致“认知负债”积累的核心话题展开。社区观点呈现多元：有人认为过度依赖AI会削弱深度思考能力，如同依赖GPS导致路线记忆退化；也有用户指出这类似历史上对文字和计算器的担忧，工具会改变技能重心而非必然降低思维能力。讨论中提到，部分用户积极利用AI辅助解决问题并记录推理过程，认为关键在于如何有效使用而非完全回避。分歧在于应对方式：有观点主张通过提高使用成本来限制访问，尤其是对未成年人；而更多声音认为我们正不可避免地走向AI优先的系统，重点应是适应而非抵制。共识在于AI确实改变了认知习惯，但对其长期影响尚无定论。

comments.author: mcv
comments.content: This seems to confirm my feeling when using AI too much. It's easy to get started, but I can feel my brain engaging less with the problem than I'm used to. It can form a barrier to real understanding, and keeps me out of my flow.I recently worked on something very complex I don't think I would have been able to tackle as quickly without AI; a hierarchical graph layout algorithm based on the Sugiyama framework, using Brandes-Köpf for node positioning. I had no prior experience with it (and I went in clearly underestimating how complex it was), and AI was a tremendous help in getting a basic understanding of the algorithm, its many steps and sub-algorithms, the subtle interactions and unspoken assumptions in it. But letting it write the actual code was a mistake. That's what kept me from understanding the intricacies, from truly engaging with the problem, which led me to keep relying on the AI to fix issues, but at that point the AI clearly also had no real idea what it was doing, and just made things worse.So instead of letting the AI see the real code, I switched from the Copilot IDE plugin to the standalone Copilot 365 app, where it could explain the principles behind every step, and I would debug and fix the code and develop actual understanding of what was going on. And I finally got back into that coding flow again.So don't let the AI take over your actual job, but use it as an interactive encyclopedia. That works much better for this kind of complex problem.
comments.content_cn:
这似乎印证了我过度使用AI时的感受。入门很容易，但我能感觉到大脑对问题的投入程度不如以往。它可能成为真正理解的障碍，让我难以进入心流状态。

最近我处理了一个非常复杂的项目——基于Sugiyama框架的分层图布局算法，采用Brandes-Köpf进行节点定位。若没有AI辅助，我不可能如此迅速地攻克这个难题。虽然我对此毫无经验（且明显低估了其复杂度），但AI在帮助我理解算法基础、多步骤流程、子算法结构以及其中微妙的相互作用和隐含前提方面发挥了巨大作用。

然而让AI直接编写代码是个错误。这使我无法理解精妙之处，未能真正沉浸于问题本身，导致我持续依赖AI修复问题。但此时AI显然也不清楚自己在做什么，反而让情况更糟。

于是我转而采用独立版Copilot 365应用替代IDE插件，不再让AI接触实际代码。在这个平台上，它能解释每个步骤的原理，由我进行调试修复，从而真正理解运行机制。最终我重新找回了编程的心流体验。

因此切勿让AI接管实际工作，而应将其视为互动百科全书。对于这类复杂问题，这种方式效果要好得多。

comments.author: sdoering
comments.content:
This reminds me of the recurring pattern with every new medium: Socrates worried writing would destroy memory, Gutenberg's critics feared for contemplation, novels were "brain softening," TV was the "idiot box."
That said, I'm not sure "they've always been wrong before" proves they're wrong now.Where I'm skeptical of this study:- 54 participants, only 18 in the critical 4th session- 4 months is barely enough time to adapt to a fundamentally new tool- "Reduced brain connectivity" is framed as bad - but couldn't efficient resource allocation also be a feature, not a bug?- Essay writing is one specific task; extrapolating to "cognition in general" seems like a stretchWhere the study might have a point:Previous tools outsourced partial processes - calculators do arithmetic, Google stores facts. LLMs can potentially take over the entire cognitive process from thinking to formulating. That's qualitatively different.So am I ideologically inclined to dismiss this? Maybe. But I also think the honest answer is: we don't know yet. The historical pattern suggests cognitive abilities shift rather than disappear. Whether this shift is net positive or negative - ask me again in 20 years.[Edit]: Formatting
comments.content_cn:
这让我想起每种新媒介出现时的循环模式：苏格拉底担心文字会摧毁记忆力，古腾堡的批评者担忧沉思能力受损，小说曾被视作"软化大脑"，电视则被称为"白痴盒子"。

不过，我不确定"历史上他们总是错的"能证明他们现在也是错的。我对这项研究的质疑点在于：
- 仅54名参与者，关键的第4阶段只有18人
- 4个月时间远不足以适应根本性的新工具
- "大脑连接性降低"被预设为负面结果——但高效资源配置难道不能是优势而非缺陷吗？
- 论文写作是特定任务，由此推及"整体认知能力"似乎牵强

这项研究可能的价值在于：
以往的工具只外包部分认知过程——计算器处理算术，谷歌存储信息。而大型语言模型有可能接管从思考到表达的全过程，这存在本质区别。

那么我是否因意识形态倾向而否定这项研究？或许。但我认为诚实的答案是：我们尚未知晓。历史模式表明认知能力会发生转移而非消失。这种转变最终是利是弊——二十年后再来问我吧。

comments.author: alt187
comments.content: It's more complex than that. The three pillars of learning are theory (finding out about the thing), practice (doing the thing) and metacognition (being right, or more importantly, wrong. And correcting yourself.). Each of those steps reinforce neural pathways. They're all essential in some form or another.Literacy, books, saving your knowledge somewhere else removes the burden of remembering everything in your head. But they don't come into effect into any of those processes. So it's an immensely bad metaphor. A more apt one is the GPS, that only leaves you with practice.That's where LLMs come in, and obliterate every single one of those pillars on any mental skill. You never have to learn a thing deeply, because it's doing the knowing for you. You never have to practice, because the LLM does all the writing for you. And of course, when it's wrong, you're not wrong. So nothing you learn.There are ways to exploit LLMs to make your brain grow, instead of shrink. You could make them into personalized teachers, catering to each student at their own rhythm. Make them give you problems, instead of ready-made solutions. Only employ them for tasks you already know how to make perfectly. Don't depend on them.But this isn't the future OpenAI or Anthropic are gonna gift us. Not today, and not in a hundred years, because it's always gonna be more profitable to run a sycophant.If we want LLMs to be the "better" instead of the "worse", we'll have to fight for it.
comments.content_cn:
事情比这更复杂。学习的三大支柱是理论（了解事物）、实践（动手操作）和元认知（做对，更重要的是做错并自我纠正）。每一步都在强化神经通路，它们都以某种形式至关重要。读写能力、书籍、将知识外存，这些方式减轻了大脑记忆的负担，但它们并未直接参与上述任何学习过程。因此这个比喻极不恰当，更贴切的比喻是GPS——它只给你留下实践环节。

这正是大语言模型介入之处，它们会摧毁任何心智技能所需的每一根支柱。你永远不需要深入学习，因为它替你完成认知；你永远不需要练习，因为它替你完成所有书写；当然，当它出错时，你也不会犯错——于是你什么都没学到。

存在利用大语言模型促进而非阻碍大脑成长的方法：可以将它们打造成个性化教师，按照每个学生的节奏因材施教；让它们提出问题而非现成答案；仅将其用于你已完全掌握的任务；不要形成依赖。

但这并非OpenAI或Anthropic将要馈赠我们的未来——现在不会，一百年后也不会，因为谄媚逢迎的服务永远更有利可图。如果我们希望大语言模型成为“进步助力”而非“退化推手”，就必须为之奋斗。

comments.author: yesco
comments.content: If we focus only on the impact on linguistics, I predict things will go something like this:As LLM use normalizes for essay writing (email, documentation, social media, etc), a pattern emerges where everyone uses an LLM as an editor. People only create rough drafts and then have their "editor" make it coherent.Interestingly, people might start using said editor prompts to express themselves, causing an increased range in distinct writing styles. Despite this, vocabulary and semantics as a whole become more uniform. Spelling errors and typos become increasingly rare.In parallel, people start using LLMs to summarize content in a style they prefer.Both sides of this gradually converge. Content gets explicitly written in a way that is optimized for consumption by an LLM, perhaps a return to something like the semantic web. Authors write content in a way that encourages a summarizing LLM to summarize as the author intends for certain explicit areas.Human languages start to evolve in a direction that could be considered more coherent than before, and perhaps less ambiguous. Language is the primary interface an LLM uses with humans, so even if LLM use becomes baseline for many things, if information is not being communicated effectively then an LLM would be failing at its job. I'm personifying LLMs a bit here but I just mean it in a game theory / incentive structure way.

如果我们仅关注对语言学的影响，我预测事情会这样发展：随着大语言模型在文章写作（邮件、文档、社交媒体等）中的使用常态化，一种模式将逐渐显现——每个人都把大语言模型当作编辑工具。人们只创作草稿，然后让这位“编辑”使其内容连贯。

有趣的是，人们可能会开始通过特定的编辑指令来表达自我，从而导致多样化的写作风格日益丰富。尽管如此，整体词汇和语义却会趋于统一。拼写错误和打字失误将越来越少见。

与此同时，人们开始使用大语言模型以自己偏好的风格来总结内容。这两个方向将逐渐融合。内容创作会明确朝着便于大语言模型处理的方向优化，或许会回归到类似语义网络的形态。作者会有意识地引导总结型大语言模型在特定领域按作者意图进行概括。

人类语言将朝着比以往更连贯、可能也更少歧义的方向演化。语言是大语言模型与人类交互的主要界面，因此即使大语言模型成为诸多事务的基础工具，若信息传递效率不足，就意味着它未能胜任职责。这里我稍拟人化地描述了大语言模型，但本意是从博弈论/激励机制的角度来阐述。

comments.author: albumen
comments.content: They view the framing of the MIT paper not just as bad science, but as a dangerous social tool that uses brain data to "consign people" to being less worthy or "stupid" for using cognitive aids. It flags the paper's alarmist findings as "pseudoscience" designed to provoke fear rather than provide rigorous insight. They highlight several "red flags" in the study's design: lack of a coherent scientific framework, methodological errors like typos, and reliance on invented, undefined terms such as "cognitive debt". They challenge the interpretation of EEG results, explaining that while the paper frames a 55% reduction in connectivity as evidence that a user's "brain sucks," such data could instead indicate increased neural efficiency, an alternative explanation the authors ignore. (EEG measures broad, noisy signals from outside the skull and is better understood as a rough index of brain state than as a precise window into specific thoughts or “intelligence.”)The hosts condemn the study’s "bafflingly weak" logic and ableist rhetoric, and advise skepticism toward "science communicators" who might profit from selling hardware or supplements related to their findings: one of the paper's lead authors, Nataliya Kosmyna, is associated with the MIT Media Lab and the development of AttentivU, a pair of glasses designed to monitor brain activity and engagement. By framing LLM use as creating a "cognitive debt," the researchers create a market for their own solution: hardware that monitors and alerts the user when they are "under-engaged". The AttentivU system can provide haptic or audio feedback when attention drops, essentially acting as the "scaffold" for the very cognitive deficits the paper warns against. The research is part of the "Fluid Interfaces" group at MIT, which frequently develops Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems like "Brain Switch" and "AVP-EEG". This context supports the hosts' suspicion that the paper’s "cognitive debt" theory may be designed to justify a need for these monitoring tools.

Summary using Claude 3.7 Sonnet:"Your Brain On Chat GPT" Paper AnalysisIn this transcript, neuroscientist Ashley and psychologist Cat critically analyze a controversial paper titled "Your Brain On Chat GPT" that claims to show negative brain effects from using large language models (LLMs).Key Issues With the Paper:Misleading EEG Analysis:The paper uses EEG (electroencephalography) to claim it measures "brain connectivity" but misuses technical methods
EEG is a blunt instrument that measures thousands of neurons simultaneously, not direct neural connections
The paper confuses correlation of brain activity with actual physical connectivity
Poor Research Design:Small sample size (54 participants with many dropouts)
Unclear time intervals between sessions
Vague instructions to participants
Controlled conditions don't represent real-world LLM use
Overstated Claims:Invented terms like "cognitive debt" without defining them
Makes alarmist conclusions not supported by data
Jumps from limited lab findings to broad claims about learning and cognition
Methodological Problems:Methods section includes unnecessary equations but lacks crucial details
Contains basic errors like incorrect filter settings
Fails to cite relevant established research on memory and learning
No clear research questions or framework
The Experts' Conclusion:"These are questions worth asking... I do really want to know whether LLMs change the way my students think about problems. I do want to know if the offloading of cognitive tasks changes my own brain and my own cognition... We need to know these things as a society, but to pretend like this paper answers those questions is just completely wrong."The experts emphasize that the paper appears designed to generate headlines rather than provide sound scientific insights, with potential conflicts of interest among authors who are associated with competing products.

论文存在的主要问题：
误导性的脑电图分析：
论文使用脑电图技术声称测量“大脑连接性”，但错误运用了技术方法
脑电图是同时测量数千神经元的粗略工具，并不能直接测量神经连接
论文将大脑活动的相关性混淆为实际的物理连接

研究设计缺陷：
样本量过小（54名参与者且多人中途退出）
实验环节间隔时间不明确
给参与者的指导语模糊不清
实验控制条件无法反映真实世界中使用大语言模型的情况

夸大其词的主张：
创造“认知负债”等未明确定义的新术语
提出数据无法支持的危言耸听结论
从有限的实验室发现直接跳跃到关于学习和认知的宽泛主张

方法论问题：
方法部分包含不必要的公式但缺乏关键细节
存在基础错误，如滤波器设置不当
未能引用记忆和学习领域已有的相关研究
缺乏明确的研究问题或理论框架

专家结论：
“这些都是值得探讨的问题……我确实很想知道大语言模型是否会改变学生思考问题的方式。我也想知道将认知任务外包是否……”

posts.title: Douglas Adams on the English–American cultural divide over "heroes"
posts.author: speckx
posts.title_cn: 道格拉斯·亚当斯谈英美文化对“英雄”认知的分歧
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕道格拉斯·亚当斯对英美文化中“英雄”概念差异的评论展开。核心话题聚焦于两国在叙事中对失败者形象的不同态度：英国文化更倾向于接纳甚至欣赏有缺陷的“失败英雄”，而美国文化则更推崇成功与能力卓越的角色。

讨论中提到，许多用户以影视作品为例印证这一差异。有人认为英国剧集《小镇疑云》中大卫·田纳特饰演的角色因工作失误被流放，体现了对“失败者”的刻画；也有用户指出美国作品如《热血警探》却以主角因过于优秀而被调职作为对比。部分用户延伸至商业文化，指出英国同事常以自嘲方式汇报工作，而美国同事则更直接自信地展示成就。

争议点在于对美国文化是否完全排斥“失败英雄”存在分歧。有用户以查理·布朗为例，反驳美国文化中缺乏“可爱的失败者”原型；也有用户列举阿拉莫战役等历史事件，认为美国同样纪念悲壮失败。此外，有观点指出“英雄”一词本身的多义性可能导致讨论偏差。

社区普遍认同文化差异确实影响叙事偏好，但对其具体表现程度和范围持有不同见解。多位用户提及宫崎骏作品中的道德复杂性，以及丹麦与美国喜剧的对比，进一步丰富了跨文化叙事的讨论维度。

comments.content_cn:
这直接关联到我和妻子观看大卫·田纳特与奥利维娅·科尔曼主演的《小镇疑云》时的感受。剧中大卫·田纳特饰演的角色明显业务能力极差——这正是他被流放到偏远小镇的原因。他搞砸了上一个案件，甚至登上全国新闻。若换成美国刑侦剧，编剧至少会为他的失败安排些情有可原的解释，或是用某种顽劣恶习或心魔作为降职的真正缘由。

但在《小镇疑云》里，田纳特的角色纯粹就是能力不足。每集都遵循固定模式：他对剧中某个角色产生怀疑，整集时间都在徒劳追查，最终发现本周的嫌疑人实则清白。不得不说，这种设定让剧集颇具娱乐性。这也导致我和妻子每集都会齐声感叹：“他工作能力实在太差了！”

（含轻微剧透）直到结局他抓获真凶时，也并非依靠自身能力。而是因为巧合与真凶的疏忽才使谜团破解。况且剧中其他角色早已被排除嫌疑。

自此我们开始留意那些“身陷困局却几乎毫无建树的普通人”类型的主角。得知亚当斯曾就此主题发表见解，实在有趣。

comments.author: arethuza
comments.content: "David Tennant's character is notably very bad at his job; that's why he got exiled to a backwater town."Worth noting that in Hot Fuzz (also featuring Olivia Coleman!) the main character is exiled to a rural location for being too good at his job.
comments.content_cn: 大卫·坦南特饰演的角色明显很不擅长自己的工作，因此被流放到一个偏远小镇。值得一提的是，在《热血警探》（同样由奥利维娅·科尔曼出演！）中，主角却是因为工作表现过于出色而被调往乡村地区。

comments.author: rylando
comments.content: What a great response by Adams! I think the acceptance, and even the celebration of failure is present among the “maker” community in the USA to some extent, which has really drawn me to it.I wonder if there’s the same outlook on failure among other creatives, would be interesting to compare the hobby communities opinions between the USA and UK.
comments.content_cn: 亚当斯的回应真是太棒了！我认为在美国的“创客”群体中，对失败的接纳甚至庆祝在某种程度上确实存在，这深深吸引了我。我想知道其他创意人士是否也有同样的失败观，比较美国和英国的爱好者社群对此的看法会很有趣。

comments.author: silveira
comments.content: This made me think about another contrast, Hayao Miyazaki. His characters ("heroes" or "villains"), usually are more morally complex and nuanced than the ones you would find in the works I typically see depicted in Hollywood. They are not just good or evil. You may not agree with their actions, but you understand the logic of it.
comments.content_cn: 这让我想起了宫崎骏的另一个对比点。他塑造的角色（无论是“英雄”还是“反派”）通常比好莱坞作品中常见的角色更具道德复杂性和层次感。这些角色并非简单的善与恶。你可能不认同他们的行为，却能理解其背后的逻辑。

comments.author: eikenberry
comments.content: One problem I have with this is that the word Hero has multiple meanings and I'm not sure we are talking of the same thing. Like which of these characters follow the classic Hero's Journey, which are just the leading characters in books, which are heroes to another character, which are labelled as a hero as pretext, which are anti-heros treated as heroes, etc. These are all very different things.
comments.content_cn: 我对这一点有个疑问：英雄这个词有多重含义，我不确定我们说的是否是同一回事。比如哪些角色遵循经典英雄之旅，哪些只是书中的主角，哪些是其他角色眼中的英雄，哪些被冠以英雄之名作为托辞，哪些又是被当作英雄对待的反英雄等等。这些都是截然不同的概念。

comments.author: cafard
comments.content: Americans don't celebrate failure?Well, there's the Alamo. There's Custer's Last Stand. There's Douglas MacArthur getting a Medal of Honor for being chased out of Luzon.And I urge American HNers to walk or drive around, and see how long it takes to see a Stars and Bars.
comments.content_cn: 美国人从不颂扬失败？那阿拉莫战役呢？卡斯特的最后抵抗呢？还有道格拉斯·麦克阿瑟因被赶出吕宋岛而获授荣誉勋章的事迹呢？我建议美国的创业者们不妨四处走走或开车转转，看看需要多久才能见到一面南方邦联旗。

comments.author: Munksgaard
comments.content: Mirroring this divide, Denmark has a TV-show called "Klovn", which is basically a copy of "Curb Your Enthusiasm" (down to the , except that while the main character in Curb is the cause of a lot of cringe moments, he always ends up getting his redemption and being the hero (at least to the viewer). In "Klovn", the main character ("Frank") causes a lot of cringe moments in the same way, but he is a tragicomic character and is almost always in the wrong.
comments.content_cn: 与这种分歧相呼应的是，丹麦有一档名为《小丑》的电视节目，它基本上是《抑制热情》的翻版（甚至连细节都如出一辙），区别在于：《抑制热情》的主角虽然制造了许多令人尴尬的时刻，但最终总能获得救赎，成为英雄（至少对观众而言）；而在《小丑》中，主角“弗兰克”以同样的方式引发了许多尴尬场面，但他却是个悲喜剧角色，几乎总是处于错误的一方。

comments.author: blenderob

comments.content_cn: 在商业场合也百分之百见过这种情况。我的英国同事在汇报业务进展时常常自嘲，而我的美国同事则自信地直接展示他们的成就。

comments.author: pfisherman

comments.content_cn: 反观查理·布朗：他之所以如此惹人喜爱，很大程度上源于他在近乎持续不断的霉运与失望面前，始终保持着不变的真诚与乐观。他正是这篇文章所说的美国人不待见的那种“可爱的失败者”典型。然而《花生漫画》及其动画作品却已成为美国流行文化的重要标志。

comments.author: workmandan
comments.content: Stephen Fry made the same remarks in a Q&A session some years ago: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8k2AbqTBxaoAs a Brit I can't agree more with both, I find American humour so hard to relate to but I guess it's just a culture thing
comments.content_cn: 斯蒂芬·弗莱几年前在一次问答环节中也发表过同样的言论：https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8k2AbqTBxao 作为一个英国人，我完全赞同两人的观点，我觉得美国式幽默很难引起共鸣，但我想这只是文化差异的问题。

comments.author: Wowfunhappy
comments.content: Interesting. The other book this makes me think of is Neverwhere by Neil Gaiman. I think Gaiman lives in America now, but he’d only recently moved as of when Neverwhere was published, and it’s a very British novel.I love the world and plot of Neverwhere, but the protagonist, Richard Mayhew, always pissed me off because he’s such a loser. I never understood why Gaiman chose him to be in charge of the story.Now I’m wondering if that’s my American sensibility.
comments.content_cn: 有趣。这让我想起尼尔·盖曼的另一本书《乌有乡》。虽然盖曼现在住在美国，但《乌有乡》出版时他才刚搬去不久，这仍是一部极具英伦特色的小说。我喜爱《乌有乡》的世界观和情节，但主人公理查德·梅休总让我恼火——他实在是个失败者。我一直不明白盖曼为何选择让他主导故事。现在我在想，这或许是我的美国式审美在作祟。

comments.author: AlanYx
comments.content: The phenomenon Adams is talking about here is largely a post-WW1 phenomenon in UK culture, related to the post-WW1 malaise. His best examples are post-WW1 (Paul Pennyfeather, Tony Last, and the book by Stephen Pile). The others arguably don't really fit (e.g., the core delight in Gulliver is the reader thinking they are smarter than Gulliver; the reader doesn't identify with him). It's not exactly a new observation... one of the motivations both Tolkien and CS Lewis had for strong characters like Aragorn was to present examples falling outside this cultural drift.
comments.content_cn: 亚当斯在此讨论的现象主要是英国文化中一战后的产物，与战后的精神萎靡状态相关。他最典型的例子都出自一战后时期（如保罗·彭尼费瑟、托尼·拉斯特，以及斯蒂芬·派尔的作品）。其他例子则未必契合（例如《格列佛游记》的核心乐趣在于读者自以为比格列佛更聪明，而非对其产生认同）。这并非全新观点……托尔金与C.S.路易斯塑造阿拉贡这类坚毅角色的动机之一，正是为了提供超越这种文化流变的典范。

comments.author: Scarblac

Isn't it the other way around in the US?Mickey always does good and always wins, that's deeply boring. Donald is flawed and relatable.
comments.content_cn: 在美国，你不能拿失败开玩笑。还有一个现象是，连环失败的唐老鸭在几个欧洲国家仍然是非常受欢迎的角色，而我们根本不在乎米老鼠。在美国情况是不是正好相反呢？米老鼠总是做好事，总是赢，这太无聊了。唐老鸭有缺点，更让人有共鸣。

comments.author: RNanoware

From this article's perspective, those protagonists are the epitome of American heroes (autonomy, mastery, purpose). No wonder they garnered such acclaim in the US. Curious if these stories are the exception rather than the rule in British YA fiction? Is the comparison unfair, since these stories were not written with the comedic genre in mind?
comments.content_cn: 虽然我对英式幽默了解甚少，但对比我童年和青少年时期阅读并在美国大受欢迎的英国小说（如《哈利·波特》《亚历克斯·莱德》）却让我觉得很有意思。从这篇文章的角度看，这些主角正是美国英雄的典范（自主、精通、目标明确）。难怪它们在美国获得了如此高的赞誉。我好奇这些故事在英国青少年文学中是否属于特例而非普遍现象？这种比较是否不公平，因为这些作品本就不是以喜剧类型为创作初衷？

comments.author: class3shock
comments.content: I forget where, but someone was talking about a similar difference in American vs British comedy looking at The Office (the American one) and Parks and Rec. In both, the format tends to be pre-conflict -> conflict -> resolution, with the episodes almost always ending on an upbeat tone. In contrast, in a British show, it tends to be pre-conflict -> conflict -> kick them while they are down. Things can get worse, the characters can be unredeemed, and the fun is they are inept, unlucky, arseholes that don't get out of the situation with a happy ever after.Americans like that humor as well (see Always Sunny in Philadelphia, Archer, etc.) but it definitely is less prevalent.
comments.content_cn: 我记不清具体出处了，但有人曾以《办公室》（美国版）和《公园与游憩》为例，讨论过美式与英式喜剧的类似差异。这两部美剧的模式往往是：冲突前兆→冲突爆发→矛盾化解，剧集几乎总是以积极向上的基调收尾。相比之下，英剧则倾向于：冲突前兆→冲突爆发→落井下石。剧情可能急转直下，角色或许毫无成长，其趣味性恰恰在于人物笨拙、倒霉、混蛋的特质，最终也不会迎来美满结局。美国人同样欣赏这类幽默（如《费城永远阳光灿烂》《 Archer》等作品），但这类风格确实不那么主流。

comments.author: MrDrDr
comments.content: This does not surprise me - and America is a big place, and I'm sure there are areas where Arthur would be seen in a similar light but I've worked in the US and the UK and this type of things reminds me of the phrase 'separated by a common language'. Slightly off topic perhaps but another area where I see a strong divide in sensibilities are the NewYorker cartoons - my wife (born in north America) thinks the are hilarious. I usually don't understand what's funny about them.
comments.content_cn: 这并不让我感到意外——美国幅员辽阔，我确信有些地方亚瑟也会被以类似眼光看待。我在美国和英国都工作过，这类事情让我想起“被共同语言分隔”的说法。或许有点跑题，但另一个让我感受到强烈情感分歧的领域是《纽约客》的漫画——我妻子（北美出生）觉得它们非常滑稽，而我通常不理解笑点何在。

comments.author: coole-wurst
comments.content: I feel like the divide is very evident of each countries version of the show "The Office". Probably a common trope at this point, but not even the dialogue, already the aesthetic tells you a lot about the perspective of the characters. While the UK office is grey, washed out and gloomy, the US office is warm, surprisingly full of life and outside shots are mostly sunny.
comments.content_cn: 我觉得各国版本《办公室》的差异非常明显。这或许已是常见套路，但无需台词，单从视觉风格就能看出角色视角的不同。英版办公室色调灰暗、沉闷压抑，美版却温暖明亮、充满生机，外景也多是阳光灿烂的画面。

comments.author: jobs_throwaway
comments.content: > In England our heroes tend to be characters who either have, or come to realise that they have, no control over their lives whatsoever – Pilgrim, Gulliver, Hamlet, Paul Pennyfeather (from Decline and Fall), Tony Last (from A Handful of Dust). We celebrate our defeats and our withdrawals – the Battle of Hastings, DunkirkI'm having rouble reconciling the first sentence with the second. comments.content_cn: 在英国，我们的英雄往往是那些对自己的生活毫无掌控力，或最终意识到这一点的角色——比如《天路历程》中的朝圣者、格列佛、哈姆雷特、《衰落与瓦解》中的保罗·彭尼费瑟、《一掬尘土》中的托尼·拉斯特。我们歌颂自己的失败与撤退——黑斯廷斯战役、敦刻尔克大撤退。我很难将第一句话与第二句联系起来。在敦刻尔克，英国人展现了对自身命运的极大掌控。是的，那确实是一场军事失利，但它如此著名且动人，正是因为普通英国人的能动性拯救了战局。或许这是我作为美国人的视角在发言。

comments.author: ChrisMarshallNY

Force them to accept you!", while British are told "Tsk. Tsk. You can't do it that way! comments.content_cn: 两种文化间的一大差异在于英国的等级制度。对我们来说，认清自身地位至关重要。我母亲是英国人，我过去常常看到这种态度。向上爬是可以的，但你需要用恰当的方式去做。美国人被告知“别忍气吞声！要让他们接受你！”，而英国人则被提醒“啧啧，你不能那样做！你得先加入他们的圈子，才能试图达到他们的层次。”英雄往往是那些安于现状的人。

comments.author: lordleft
comments.content: As much as I love American upbeat-ness (I'm American) I think that our hatred of failure and our strained optimism puts a tremendous psychological pressure on us. Sometimes, we fail, and that's okay. Sometimes, we lose, and that's just life. I think that's an essential part of growing up, and our collective denial of that makes me feel like we, as a people, are not quite mature.
comments.content_cn: 虽然我欣赏美国式的乐观精神（我本人就是美国人），但我认为我们对失败的厌恶以及那种强撑的乐观态度，实际上给我们带来了巨大的心理压力。有时候，失败在所难免，这没什么大不了；有时候，失去也是人生常态。我认为这正是成长过程中不可或缺的一部分，而我们整个社会对此的集体否认，让我感觉作为一个民族，我们似乎还不够成熟。

comments.author: sarchertech
comments.content: I think it could just be that America is a much bigger market with much higher production values in TV and Film, so British people get their fill of competent, triumphant heroes from American media.America has plenty of beloved sad sacks too. Charlie Brown, Donald Duck, Goofy, George Costanza, Eeyore (originally British but very popular in America and popularized by Disney) to name a few.British media has carved out a bit of a niche for itself, but British people are also consuming other English language media.And you also have plenty of British media where the hero is competent, triumphant, masterful, and autonomous with (frequent if not ubiquitous) standard happy endings. Lord of the Rings, Harry Potter, Sherlock Holmes, Doctor Who.
comments.content_cn: 我认为这可能是因为美国市场规模更大，影视制作水准更高，所以英国人早已通过美国媒体看够了那些能力超群、无往不利的英雄形象。美国其实也有很多备受喜爱的倒霉蛋角色，比如查理·布朗、唐老鸭、高飞狗、乔治·科斯坦扎、小驴屹耳（虽源自英国但经迪士尼推广后在美国极受欢迎）等等。英国媒体确实形成了自己独特的风格定位，但英国观众同样也在消费其他英语媒体内容。况且英国本土也不乏展现主角能力卓越、大获全胜、掌控全局且结局圆满（即使非千篇一律也属常见）的经典作品，例如《指环王》《哈利·波特》《福尔摩斯》《神秘博士》等系列。

comments.author: scrumper

comments.author: jacquesm

comments.content_cn: 这部电影是一系列精心拼接的恶搞片段，最终串联成一个完整故事。其巧妙之处甚至在于反向作用——当你先看过《热血警探》，多年后再看其他电影时，会突然意识到那些桥段的出处原来在此。

comments.author: gbear605

comments.content_cn: 讽刺的是，吉卜力改编的《地海传说》（原著作者为美国作家勒古恩）遭遇滑铁卢，部分原因在于宫崎骏将故事重心从原著转向了英雄与反派的对立。

comments.author: NoboruWataya

comments.content_cn: 这篇帖子主要还是关于幽默——美国人真的会拿那些事情开玩笑吗？或许他们庆祝的不是失败，而是战争？

comments.author: CodeMage
comments.content: One of my favorite details about Neal Stephenson's "Snow Crash" is the name he chose for his main character: Hiro Protagonist. It's not just a lovely bit of wordplay, it immediately makes you think about whether the protagonist is a "hero" or not.This overloaded meaning of the word "hero" is especially pertinent when discussing the differences between the interpretation of "hero" in US culture and other cultures. Outside overt dictatorships, the US is the only country I know of where people are taught that anyone who serves or served in the military is automatically a "hero", regardless of whether they've actually done anything that would normally be considered heroic.
comments.content_cn: 关于尼尔·斯蒂芬森的《雪崩》，我最喜欢的细节之一是他为主角选择的名字：广·主角。这不仅是巧妙的文字游戏，还立刻让人思考主角是否算得上“英雄”。在讨论美国文化与其他文化对“英雄”理解的差异时，“英雄”一词的这种多重含义尤为贴切。除了明显的专制国家外，美国是我所知的唯一一个教导人们认为任何服役或曾服役于军队的人都自动成为“英雄”的国家，无论他们是否真正做过通常被视为英勇的事迹。

comments.author: TheOtherHobbes
comments.content: It's not just deprecation, it's systemic understatement. It drives non-British people insane because everyone is talking in code.And some of the meaning is hidden in intonation.If someone says "Interesting..." that can mean "That's the dumbest thing I've ever heard" or "Might be worth a look, but not a priority right now." Or maybe "That's very suspicious.""That's quite good" usually means "Very good, I like it!"
comments.content_cn: 这不仅仅是含蓄，而是一种系统性的轻描淡写。它让非英国人抓狂，因为每个人都在用暗语交流。有些含义隐藏在语调中。如果有人说“有意思……”，那可能意味着“这是我听过最蠢的事”，或者“或许值得一看，但目前不是重点”，又或者是“这很可疑”。“相当不错”通常意味着“非常好，我喜欢！”

comments.author: svat
comments.content: OP here (though I don't claim any special insight, as I said).It would be interesting to consider the differences between the Charlie Brown and Arthur Dent character archetypes.One difference seems to me exactly the undying earnestness and optimism you mentioned: in a way, Charlie Brown and other American characters like him are simply not touched by failure (even if bad things happen to them), because of their optimism[1]. This makes them lovable: we appreciate them for this quality that we (most of the audience) do not have.[1]: (or lack of self-awareness, in some other cases mentioned here like Homer Simpson or Peter Griffin)Arthur Dent, on the other hand, is not gifted with undying optimism. He's constantly moaning about things, starting with his house and his planet being destroyed. This makes him relatable more than lovable: he's not a “lovable loser” (and for the right audience, does not seem a “loser” at all), he is just us, “my kind of guy” — we feel kinship rather than appreciation. We relate to the moaning (if Arthur Dent were to remain unfailingly optimistic, he'd be… different), whereas if Charlie Brown were to lose his optimism or if Homer were to say "D'oh!" to complain about big things in life rather than hurting his thumb or whatever, they would become less of the endearing American institutions they are IMO.
comments.content_cn: 原帖作者在此（不过正如我所说，我并没有什么特别的见解）。思考一下查理·布朗和阿瑟·邓特这两种角色原型的差异会很有意思。在我看来，一个区别恰恰在于你提到的那种永不消逝的真诚与乐观：某种程度上，查理·布朗和他那样的美国角色根本不会被失败所影响（即使遭遇不幸），因为他们的乐观主义[1]。这让他们显得可爱：我们欣赏这种我们（大多数观众）所不具备的特质。[1]：（或者在某些其他案例中，如荷马·辛普森或彼得·格里芬，表现为缺乏自我认知）另一方面，阿瑟·邓特并没有被赋予永恒的乐观。他总是在抱怨，从自己的房子到星球被毁。这让他更易引起共鸣而非让人觉得可爱：他不是一个“可爱的失败者”（对于合适的受众来说，他根本不像个“失败者”），他就是我们，“我这类人”——我们感受到的是亲近而非欣赏。我们理解那种抱怨（如果阿瑟·邓特始终保持乐观，他将会……变得不同），而如果查理·布朗失去了乐观，或者荷马用“唉！”来抱怨人生大事而不是因为砸到拇指之类的小事，他们作为那些令人喜爱的美国经典角色的特质就会减弱。

comments.author: deltarholamda
comments.content: His point of high church vs. Protestantism is a good one. We in the US practice a kind of competitive Protestantism designed--at least partly, if not mostly--to make the adherents feel good about themselves. There is a distinct difference between submission and proselytizing.There is also something to the state of empire as well. The British empire had been in steady decline for a very long time before Adams or Fry started making people laugh, whereas the American empire has been ascending quickly since WWII. This sort of gestalt is hard to ignore and will certainly influence things. For example, would a 'Blackadder' sell as well in 1890? This is around the same time 'King Solomon's Mines' was selling briskly, and Haggard's story is instantly recognizable by any modern Hollywood writer.On some level Americans are British people time-displaced by a couple of generations.

comments.author: freedomben
comments.content: Yes, definitely a culture thing. I had a very difficult time finding most British humor funny when I was younger, but my personality combination of loving humor and comedy and also being incredibly interested in people, drove me to want to understand why British humor was funny when most of the time it just seemed so absurd.It was a multi-decade path so it's very difficult to identify progression points, but slowly through exposure I began to "get it" and now I adore British comedy and humor. I still adore American comedy and humor as well, but the more exposure to the culture I got, the more I understood it.Obviously that's just anecdotal, but I personally find it strong evidence that the humor divide is indeed cultural. The more similar cultures are to begin with, the easier the leap is.To me the most exciting part of this is that it means there are thousands of other cultures on this planet that have humor that I have not unlocked yet. Someday I hope to!Edit: for a very fascinating example of differences, I love comparing the UK version of the office to the US version of the office. To many Americans, David Brent mostly just came off mean and an asshole, even a poisonous one, whereas Michael Scott comes off as eccentric and clueless and unable to read the room, but overall a mostly good guy. That perception makes David Brent kind of hateable whereas Michael Scott kind of lovable.Another fascinating point of comparison is the UK version of ghosts, versus the US version of ghosts. I'll leave comparisons and contrasts on those to others as I haven't watched all of the UK version of ghosts yet. I'd be fascinated to hear what others think of that, and the office for that matter.
comments.content_cn:
是的，这绝对是文化差异的问题。年轻时，我很难理解大多数英式幽默的笑点，但由于我既热爱幽默喜剧，又对人性充满好奇，这种性格组合驱使我想要弄明白：为什么英式幽默在多数情况下显得如此荒诞，却依然有趣。这是一个跨越数十年的过程，很难明确划分阶段，但通过不断接触，我逐渐“开了窍”，如今深深爱上了英式喜剧和幽默。当然，我依然欣赏美式喜剧和幽默，但文化接触越多，理解就越深。

虽然这只是个人经历，但我认为这有力证明了幽默的隔阂确实源于文化差异。文化背景越相近，理解起来就越容易。

最让我兴奋的是，这意味着世界上还有成千上万种文化中的幽默尚未被我领悟。希望有一天我能做到！

编辑：举一个有趣的差异例子，我喜欢比较英国版和美版《办公室》。对许多美国人来说，大卫·布伦特显得刻薄、讨厌甚至恶毒，而迈克尔·斯科特则显得古怪、迟钝、不懂察言观色，但总体上是个好人。这种认知让大卫·布伦特招人反感，而迈克尔·斯科特却有点可爱。

另一个有趣的对比是英国版和美版《鬼魂》……

comments.content: At least in the case of Harry Potter specifically, there's actually a few things that contributed to its success outside of it having a traditionally successful Real American Hero™.First off, we need to remember that it was cribbing from a lot of other "kid goes to magic boarding school" books out there. The difference in sales success is down to the fact that JKR got a better US publisher. Scholastic has an unfair advantage in the young adult and graded reader markets called the "Scholastic Book Fair". Basically, it's a travelling bookstore event set up in US schools where they sell kids books. If you wanted to start a YA phenomenon in the US, especially back in the 2000s, that was the perfect way to do it.For similar reasons, Bone outsold a good chunk of other western comics purely because of the fact that Scholastic was the only company willing to touch it.Another factor is that its obvious Britishisms come across as fantastical to American audiences. I mean, who in America even knows what a boarding school is? This is the same reason why Naruto did so well in America, even though most of the things that seem unique about its world are just fantastic versions of bog-standard ninja tropes.[0] This is the same reason why Naruto arguably did better in America than in its native Japan.
comments.content_cn: 至少就《哈利·波特》而言，其成功除了传统的美式英雄设定外，还有几个关键因素。首先，它借鉴了许多其他“孩子进入魔法寄宿学校”题材的作品。销量差异主要归功于J.K.罗琳找到了更优秀的美国出版商——学乐集团。该集团在青少年和分级读物市场拥有名为“学乐书展”的不公平优势，这是一种在美国学校举办的流动书店活动，直接向孩子们售书。若想在21世纪初的美国打造青少年阅读热潮，这无疑是绝佳途径。类似地，《骨头历险记》漫画的销量远超其他西方漫画，正是因为学乐是唯一愿意推广它的公司。另一个因素是其鲜明的英伦风格对美国读者显得奇幻神秘——毕竟有多少美国人真正了解寄宿学校？这同样解释了《火影忍者》在美国的成功：作品中看似独特的世界观，本质上只是对经典忍者题材的奇幻化演绎。这也部分说明了为何《火影忍者》在美国的市场表现甚至可能超越其本土日本。

comments.author: dbspin
comments.content: David Brent is poisonous, and indeed hatable. The point of the British version of the show is not that he's more tolerable or likeable to the British. If anything it's more pointed how awful he is this side of the water, given the preponderance of bosses exactly like this. What makes the show work in the UK (and Ireland), is a greater cultural willingness to see the worst aspects of reality reflected in entertainment. Versus the focus on escapism in even the most grim US television - i.e.: Tony Soprano is a monster, but he also has charisma and glamour. Walter White is dying and becoming more and more amoral, but he also goes from being a dork to a badass. Both characters are utter glamorisations of what their real life counterparts would be like. Along with the surrealism there's a genuine existentialism to the darkest of UK comedy - from early Alan Partridge to Nighty Night. An actual interest in examining the nature of cruelty and suffering.

posts.title: eBay explicitly bans AI "buy for me" agents in user agreement update
posts.author: bdcravens
posts.title_cn: eBay在用户协议更新中明确禁止AI“代购”代理程序
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕eBay更新用户协议明确禁止AI“代购”代理展开。核心争议在于AI购物代理的实用性与平台禁令的合理性。有用户认为AI代理能有效监控二手市场，根据自然语言描述自动寻找符合预算和规格的商品，提升购物效率。也有用户指出此类代理可能被用于大规模炒货或代发货，导致商品刚售出就被立即重新上架，扰乱市场秩序。讨论中提到，平台如何有效识别AI代理存在技术困难，尤其当代理使用真实浏览器时。部分用户认为现有搜索提醒功能已能满足需求，无需AI介入；另有观点指出，随着Agent Commerce Protocol等标准发展，此类禁令可能只是过渡措施。社区普遍认同AI在比价和筛选方面的辅助价值，但对全自动购买二手商品的风险表示担忧。

comments.author: cortesoft
comments.content: This reminds me so much of an old World of Warcraft addon i used in 2005-6 or so… I believe it was called ‘bottom feeder’ or something.Basically, you would leave your character logged in sitting at the auction house. It would observe auctions for a while, and generate pricing data and sales data. Then, you would enable automatic mode, and it would automatically bid/buy any item that someone put up for sale if the price was much lower than normal.You would leave it running overnight, or whatever, then come back to go pick up all the items it bought, and then you would go back to the auction house and sell all your items you bought at the correct price.Basically, you would see buy auctions created by people who didn’t realize what the correct price should be and sold too cheaply. Since this was an automated system, you could beat any human to take advantage of the deal.I made a ton of in game currency doing this.After a few months they changed the auction rules to prevent this… add-ons could no longer directly bid on items, and you had to sit there and click “buy” whenever the script found a good deal. This severely limited the amount you could make with the script.Basically this mirrors the eBay timeline, with the same reasons I am guessing… eBay (like WoW) doesn’t want bots collecting arbitrage.
comments.content_cn:
这让我想起2005-06年左右用过的一个《魔兽世界》老插件，好像叫“底价收购者”之类的。它的运作方式是：让角色挂在拍卖行下线，插件会先观察拍卖行情，收集价格和销售数据。然后开启自动模式，一旦有人上架的商品远低于市场价，它就会自动竞价或购买。

你可以让它整夜运行，回来后收取所有低价购入的物品，再以正常价格挂回拍卖行转卖。本质上就是捕捉那些不了解行情、定价过低的玩家发布的拍卖。由于是自动化系统，总能比手动操作的玩家更快抢到便宜货。

我靠这个赚了大量游戏币。几个月后，游戏修改了拍卖规则——插件不能再直接竞价，必须手动点击“购买”按钮。这极大限制了脚本的盈利效率。

其实这和eBay的发展轨迹很相似，我猜原因也类似：就像《魔兽世界》一样，eBay也不希望机器人利用差价套利。

comments.author: celeritascelery
comments.content: And I prefer to use sniping bots because they let me revise my bid all the way up until the auction ends. If I put a bid on something and then sleep on it and decide I don’t actually want to pay that much, I can lower my bid or cancel it. If I bid with eBay directly then I loose that flexibility. It has nothing to do with trying to outsmart people or be sneaky.
comments.content_cn: 我更喜欢使用狙击机器人，因为它们允许我在拍卖结束前随时修改出价。如果我对某件商品出价后，经过一夜思考决定并不想支付那么多，我可以降低或取消出价。如果直接在eBay上出价，我就会失去这种灵活性。这与试图智取他人或耍心机毫无关系。

comments.author: giobox

comments.content_cn: 热门汽车拍卖网站bringatrailer.com的竞拍流程也采用类似方式运作，其独特之处在于让在线观看拍卖尾声变得颇具趣味性，尤其是当人们紧张地关注最终出价候选者进入冷却阶段时，每辆待售车辆的评论区总会爆发出热烈讨论。正如您所举的例子，在拍卖结束前的两分钟内，每次新出价都会将拍卖时钟再延长两分钟，直到连续两分钟无人加价，获胜者才真正赢得拍卖。

comments.author: cge
comments.content: In my experience, most purely online auctions, other than eBay, do work that way. Numerous auction houses, for example, including essentially all the major ones, have their auctions online now: when they are hybrid, that involves online live bidding where an online bid will cause the auctioneer in the room to keep the lot open for more bids; when they are "timed" or "online only", times are extended in some way on bids near the deadline. It does, in fact, work much better. There is still an advantage to bidding very late: there is no disadvantage, and it lowers bids in cases of irrational or imperfect opposing bidders. But it limits that process to something that can be done by hand.eBay really seems to be the only auctioneer using the snipable process it uses.
comments.content_cn: 根据我的经验，除了eBay之外，大多数纯在线拍卖确实采用这种方式运作。例如，许多拍卖行，包括几乎所有主要拍卖行，现在都提供在线拍卖：当采用混合模式时，在线出价会促使现场拍卖师继续开放拍品以接受更多竞价；当采用“定时”或“仅在线”模式时，临近截止时间的出价会以某种方式延长拍卖时间。实际上，这种方式运作效果要好得多。在最后时刻出价仍有优势：这没有任何坏处，并且在面对非理性或不完美的竞拍对手时能降低成交价。但它将这一过程限制在可以手动操作的范围内。eBay似乎是唯一使用其可截标流程的拍卖平台。

comments.author: dspillett
comments.content: > I never understood why eBay set things up to enable sniping.I've seen studies on auction method that suggest the difference in the final price (between explicit end time and the more traditional extend-until-bidding-stops method) is negligible for online auctions except in a few special cases. This is a marked difference from the expectation that, like a real-world in-person auction, the extending deadline might encourage further spur-of-the-moment bidding.Whether it makes much difference to the final price or not is immaterial though if the buyers believe that it does. This is one of the (several) reasons why eBay won out against similar competition in the early days: buyers felt they were getting a better deal by being able to snipe so favoured eBay with more of their attention and this brought more sellers to the platform (which attracted more buyers, and so on round the loop). It is telling that to deal with the extra load imposed on the system by external bots refreshing pages and putting in automated bids, instead of switching to an extending auction model they implemented what is almost a built-in sniping feature.Auction sites have to be very careful (or just very lucky) in their messaging, to convince both sellers and buyers that they are getting a good deal - any major change to how eBay works could upset the balance that they currently have in that regard and start a flood in the other direction (the more people leave, the more other people will think about leaving) to the building toward critical mass that was how they won out in those early days.
comments.content_cn: 我一直不明白eBay为何要设置狙击出价功能。拍卖方式的研究表明，除了少数特殊情况，在线拍卖的最终价格差异（在明确结束时间和传统"出价不停则延长"模式之间）微乎其微。这与现实拍卖中延长截止时间可能刺激即兴出价的预期形成鲜明对比。不过最终价格是否真有差异并不重要，只要买家相信存在差异就够了。这正是eBay早期能在同类竞争中胜出的关键原因之一：买家认为狙击出价能获得更优惠的交易，因而更关注eBay平台，这吸引了更多卖家入驻（进而吸引更多买家，形成良性循环）。值得注意的是，为应对外部机器人频繁刷新页面和自动出价带来的系统负荷，eBay没有转向延长拍卖模式，反而推出了近乎内置的狙击功能。拍卖网站必须谨慎把握宣传策略（或足够幸运），让买卖双方都确信自己获得了公平交易——任何对eBay运作机制的重大调整都可能打破现有平衡，引发用户大规模流失（离场者越多，越会引发更多人考虑离开……）

comments.author: Fwirt
comments.content:
This was my belief for many years, but then I tried sniping (with the same prices I was putting as my maximum bid before!) and my success rate skyrocketed and the prices I was paying dropped.It seems that despite repeated reminders and explanations, there are three groups of people using eBay "incorrectly" that make the sniping strategy viable:
1) People who do not understand proxy bidding and think that they "need" to repeatedly bid in increments.
2) People who are irrational about their price ceiling and are willing to bid above their price ceiling because they want to "win".
3) People who want to drive up the price either to deprive others of a good deal, or to drive up the price on behalf of the seller by starting a bidding war with the two above groups.From a sellers perspective it is common to deal with buyers who won't pay because they paid "more than they wanted", although this is against the eBay ToS and a bid is a contract to purchase the item, because there are few consequences for not doing so.For some reason, auctions with more bidders seem to attract more bidders, whereas auctions with zero bids seem to go unnoticed. I wonder if this has to do with eBay's search ranking algorithm or some other irrational behavior that I don't understand. At any rate, bidding with 5 or less seconds left to go seems to defeat the above behaviors. I find it distasteful and irrational but it works so I put up with it.eBay's reputation and trust network is really what makes it a viable product at this point. Given how unreliable Facebook Marketplace buyers are and how many scams are present, I would hesitate to conduct any major transactions beyond a local area.
comments.content_cn:
多年来我一直这么认为，但后来我尝试了狙击策略（使用与我之前设置的最高出价相同的价格！），结果我的成功率飙升，实际支付价格反而下降了。尽管平台反复提醒和解释，似乎仍有三类人在"错误"使用eBay，这使得狙击策略行之有效：

posts.title: Can you slim macOS down?
posts.author: ingve
posts.title_cn: 你能精简macOS吗？
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕“能否精简macOS”展开，核心争议在于macOS是否过于臃肿以及精简的必要性。部分用户认为系统占用资源过多，尤其在CI虚拟机和服务器场景下，无头版或最小化安装选项的缺失导致资源浪费；有用户指出，macOS虽通过Unix认证，但实际兼容性需关闭系统完整性保护，这引发了对系统设计理念的讨论。在精简动机上，有人认为关键并非CPU或内存占用，而是用户对系统控制感的缺失，例如后台进程频繁唤醒影响使用体验。也有用户反驳称现代硬件性能充足，无需过度优化微末进程。讨论中提到，部分工具如App Tamer可帮助管理系统进程，但整体上社区对苹果未提供官方精简方案感到不满。共识在于，许多用户希望获得更轻量级的macOS选项，尤其在专业场景中，但对其实现路径和实际效益存在分歧。

comments.author: pxc
comments.content: There's a lot of chatter here about macOS' Unix certification. But in a post shared by another user, it appears that the actual content of that Unix certification vindicates OP— macOS' official Unix compatibility requires disabling SIP:> So, if you want your installation of macOS 15.0 to pass the UNIX® 03 certification test suites, you need to disable System Integrity Protection, enable the root account, enable core file generation, disable timeout coalescing, mount any APFS partitions with the strictatime option, format your APFS partitions case-sensitive (by default, APFS is case-insensitive, so you’ll need to reinstall), disable Spotlight, copy the binaries uucp, uuname, uustat, and uux from /usr/bin to /usr/local/bin and the binaries uucico and uuxqt from /usr/sbin to /usr/local/bin, set the setuid bit on all of these binaries, add /usr/local/bin to your PATH before /usr/bin and /usr/sbin, enable the uucp service, and handle the mystery issues listed in the four Temporary Waivers.https://www.osnews.com/story/141633/apples-macos-unix-certif...So it seems very fair to say then, that features like SIP and the SSV are genuine turns away from Unix per se, even given the fact of the certification.

comments.author: zbentley
comments.content: I suspect that Oakley could have explained that, but the thesis stands even without the asterisk, and explaining it would have an issue:This is going to piss off some Linux folks, but when communicating from a big pulpit about how to bypass parts of MacOS, it's important to be aware that the vast majority of MacOS users are casual, nontechnical users. As such, a popular blog posting "here's how to bypass SIP/SSV lock/whatever" would lead to a wave of users disabling it for less-than-great reasons (aesthetics, conviction that e.g. a given service was causing their system slowness when that service's resource usage was actually symptomatic of something else orchestrated by MacOS going wrong). Those decisions have side effects:- Folks brick or break their computers, potentially in a way that voids the warranty or support contracts (I hope that software bypasses don't trigger this, but I am cynical).- Folks chasing a "cleanliness vibe" leave a lot of the system security off once they're done. Someone else in this thread pointed out that without SSV the security of MacOS is on par with most Linux, but MacOS users are a lot bigger attack risk than Linux users: there are more of them, they're wealthier and thus identified as targets of choice by malware/people, and, again--they're casual users and don't have good security spider sense. This isn't a blanket endorsement of every restriction/security feature with no opt-out that MacOS has, just an observation that its userbase is at higher risk for attack than some others--lower than windows, but higher than Linux users.- Folks induce breakage that bricks their computers on a delay, e.g. during the next system update something chokes after encountering a totally unauthorized/unexpected service geometry and crashes hard enough to cause data loss.I'm not saying that stuff like SSV-rw should be secret, just that it's probably for the best to not discuss it front and center in a widely-read informational blog whose content is geared towards (power) users rather than technicians. To phrase it with a different example: if someone Googles "how to disable XProtect (antimalware)", great, go nuts. But it's probably for the best that a popular article about "can you reduce resource usage by shutting down system launchd services" doesn't have a "here's how to elevate your permissions and disable whatever you like" blurb, and instead settles for an answer of "no, that's not supported."

comments.author: kbolino
comments.content: Indeed, these processes are not all sitting there doing nothing.Two processes in particular have been this exact sort of problem for me: mds_stores and mediaanalysisd. On three separate Macs (all Apple Silicon), I've observed the case heating up whenever the computer is plugged in but not actively being used. Assuming Activity Monitor is more or less accurate, the culprit seems to be those two, who always have massive amounts of accumulated CPU time, but never seem to actually be using CPU when watched. I suspect, given what they supposedly do, that they're also needlessly exhausting SSD write cycles, but that's harder to analyze/prove. Naturally, they are also in the untouchable area of the file system. Completely disabling Spotlight, which you can do without disabling SIP, seems to always fix this problem, albeit at the cost of seriously decreased usability. I've also had mixed results with just limiting the categories of Spotlight indexing in System Settings.
comments.content_cn: 确实，这些进程并非都无所事事。对我而言，有两个进程尤其成为这类问题的典型：mds_stores和mediaanalysisd。在三台不同的Mac电脑（均为苹果芯片机型）上，我观察到只要接通电源但未主动使用电脑，机身就会发热。假设活动监视器的数据大致准确，罪魁祸首似乎是这两个进程——它们总是累积大量的CPU时间，但在实际观察时却似乎从未真正占用CPU。考虑到它们宣称的功能，我怀疑它们还在无谓地消耗SSD的写入寿命，不过这较难分析或证实。自然，它们也位于文件系统的受保护区域，无法轻易干预。完全禁用聚焦搜索（可在不关闭系统完整性保护的情况下操作）似乎总能解决此问题，尽管代价是实用性大幅降低。若仅在系统设置中限制聚焦搜索的索引类别，效果则参差不齐。

posts.title: I was banned from Claude for scaffolding a Claude.md file?
posts.author: hugodan
posts.title_cn: "我因搭建Claude.md文件而被禁止使用Claude？"
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕用户因创建“Claude.md”文件而被Anthropic封禁账户的事件展开。核心争议在于封禁原因是否合理，以及用户对AI服务的使用边界。

有用户指出，类似行为可能触发了平台的“提示注入”安全机制，导致自动封禁。也有用户分享自身经历，表示曾因实验性使用不同AI模型交互而被封，但更换账户后未再出现问题。讨论中提到，部分用户对Anthropic的服务稳定性提出批评，包括终端闪烁、高错误率等技术问题。

在应对策略上，社区出现分歧。有人认为应转向本地化部署LLM以规避审查和封禁风险，甚至提出分布式算力共享的设想；也有用户认为当前企业部署的本地模型能力远落后于Claude，短期内难以替代。

共识在于，用户普遍对AI服务商缺乏透明度的封禁机制感到不满，但对其技术依赖仍在持续。部分用户通过使用临时账户来降低风险，反映出对中心化服务商政策反复的无奈。

comments.author: bastard_op

I even started paying for MAX plan as I've been using it effectively to write software now (I am NOT a developer).Lately it's gotten entirely flaky, where chat's will just stop working, simply ignoring new prompots, and otherwise go unresponsive. I wondered if maybe I'm pissing them off somehow like the author of this article did.Now even worse is Claude seemingly has no real support channel. You get their AI bot, and that's about it. Eventually it will offer to put you through to a human, and then tell you that don't wait for them, they'll contact you via email. That email never comes after several attempts.I'm assuming at this point any real support is all smoke and mirrors, meaning I'm paying for a service now that has become almost unusable, with absolutely NO means of support to fix it. I guess for all the cool tech, customer support is something they have not figured out.I love Claude as it's an amazing tool, but when it starts to implode on itself that you actually require some out-of-box support, there is NONE to be had. Grok seems the only real alternative, and over my dead body would I use anything from "him".

更糟糕的是，Claude似乎没有真正的支持渠道。你只能联系到他们的AI客服机器人，仅此而已。最终系统会建议你转接人工客服，却又告知无需等待，他们会通过邮件联系你。但多次尝试后，这些邮件从未到来。

目前看来，任何所谓的真实支持都只是幌子。这意味着我现在花钱购买的服务几乎无法使用，且完全没有获得支持的途径来解决问题。我猜尽管技术很酷，但客户支持是他们尚未攻克的难题。

我热爱Claude，它本是个绝佳的工具，但当它自身开始崩溃、真正需要外部支持时，却根本无处求援。Grok似乎是唯一可行的替代品，但我宁死也不会使用“那个人”旗下的任何产品。

posts.title: Threat actors expand abuse of Microsoft Visual Studio Code
posts.author: vinnyglennon
posts.title_cn: 威胁行为者扩大对Microsoft Visual Studio Code的滥用
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕黑客滥用微软Visual Studio Code自动执行任务功能的安全威胁展开。核心争议在于VS Code的安全机制是否足够有效，以及用户责任与软件设计的平衡问题。

有人认为VS Code的工作区信任机制提供了明确警告，用户若选择信任项目则应自行承担风险。也有用户指出这种设计过度依赖用户判断，即使经验丰富的开发者也可能无法准确评估风险。讨论中提到自动执行任务的实际用途存疑，部分观点认为IDE不应默认允许自动执行任意代码，这让人联想到宏病毒问题。

社区普遍认同在容器内开发应成为默认工作流程以降低风险。分歧点在于：一方认为现有安全提示已足够，另一方则认为软件应默认采取更严格限制。还有用户对基于Web技术的桌面应用安全性表示担忧，认为其攻击面过大。

comments.author: Tyriar
comments.content: VS Code team member here :wave:As called out elsewhere, workspace trust is literally the protection here which is being circumvented. You're warned when you open a folder whether you trust the origin/authors with pretty strong wording. Sure you may find this annoying, but it's literally a security warning in a giant modal that forces you to chose.Even if automatic tasks were disabled by default, you'd still be vulnerable if you trust the workspace. VS Code is an IDE and the core and extensions can execute code based on files within the folder in order to provide rich features like autocomplete, compilation, run tests, agentic coding, etc.Before workspace trust existed, we started noticing many extensions and core features having their own version of workspace trust warnings popping up. Workspace trust unified this into a single in your face experience. It's perfectly fine to not trust the folder, you'll just enter restricted mode that will protect you and certain things will be degraded like language servers may not run, you don't be able to debug (executes code in vscode/launch.json), etc.Ultimately we're shipping developer tool that can do powerful things like automating project compilation or dependency install when you open a folder. This attack vector capitalizes on neglectful developers that ignore a scary looking security warning. It certainly happens in practice, but workspace trust is pretty critical to the trust model of VS Code and is also an important part to improve the UX around it as we annoy you a _single_ time when you open the folder, not several times from various components using a JIT notification approach. I recall many discussions happening around the exact wording of the warning, it's a difficult to communicate concept in the small amount of words that it needs to use.My recommendation is to use the check box to trust the parent or configure trusted folders. I personally have all my safe git clones in a dev/ folder which I configured to trust, but I also have a playground/ folder where I put random projects that I don't know much about and decide at the time I open something.
comments.content_cn:
VS Code团队成员在此：正如其他地方提到的，工作区信任正是此处被绕过的保护机制。当你打开文件夹时，系统会以非常强烈的措辞提醒你是否信任该来源/作者。你可能会觉得这很烦人，但这确实是一个强制你做出选择的大型模态窗口中的安全警告。

即使默认禁用自动任务，如果你信任工作区，仍然可能面临风险。VS Code是一个集成开发环境，其核心功能和扩展可以根据文件夹内的文件执行代码，以提供丰富的功能，如自动补全、编译、运行测试、智能编码等。

在工作区信任功能出现之前，我们开始注意到许多扩展和核心功能各自弹出类似工作区信任的警告。工作区信任将这些统一为一个显眼的集中提示。不信任文件夹是完全没问题的，你将进入受保护的限制模式，但某些功能会受限，例如语言服务器可能无法运行，你将无法调试（通过vscode/launch.json执行代码）等。

归根结底，我们提供的开发者工具能够执行强大的操作，例如在打开文件夹时自动编译项目或安装依赖。这种攻击方式利用了开发者忽视看似可怕的安全警告的疏忽。这种情况在实践中确实会发生，但工作区信任对于VS Code的信任模型至关重要，也是提升……的重要部分。

comments.author: CWuestefeld
comments.content: I suspect that you're relying too heavily on the user here. Even for myself, a very experienced developer, I don't have a flash of insight over what my risk exposure might be for what I'm opening at this moment. I don't have a comprehensive picture of all the implications, all I'm thinking is "I need to open this file and twiddle some text in it". Expecting us to surface from our flow, think about the risks and make an informed decision might on the surface seem like a fair expectation, but in the real world, I don't think it's going to happen.Your recommendation makes sense as a strategy to follow ahead of time, before you're in that flow state. But now you're relying on people to have known about the question beforehand, and have this strategy worked out ahead of time.If you're going to rely on this so heavily, maybe you should make that strategy more official, and surface it to users ahead of time - maybe in some kind of security configuration wizard or something. Relying on them to interrupt flow and work it out is asking too much when it's a security question that doesn't have obvious implications.
comments.content_cn:
我怀疑你在这里过于依赖用户了。即使对我这样经验丰富的开发者来说，我也无法瞬间洞察当前打开文件可能带来的风险暴露。我无法全面把握所有潜在影响，满脑子想的只是"我需要打开这个文件并修改其中某些文本"。期望我们中断工作状态、思考风险并做出明智决定，表面看似合理，但在现实世界中我认为这很难实现。

你的建议作为预先制定的策略很有道理，但这要求人们在进入工作状态前就了解这个问题并提前制定好策略。如果你要如此依赖这种方式，或许应该让这个策略更加正式化，并提前向用户展示——比如通过某种安全配置向导之类的工具。在安全影响并不明显的情况下，要求用户中断工作流程自行解决问题，这个要求实在太高了。

comments.author: jmyeet
comments.content: This particular vulnerability relied upon passing the require function to a scope to allow the loading and running of arbitrary code. This is what I tend to call a blacklist approach. You're saying in this sandbox certain features can't be used because they will allow escape.The alternative is a whitelist approach. Instead of disallowing dangerous features you're enabling only the features you need.So a build system like Gradle or Maven (same thing really) has a limited set of primitives it is allowing access to. It's not loading, say, the entire JVM and all the Java core libraries and then listing all those you can't use.You see the difference? If nothing else, the blacklist approach is going to fail when the virtual machine (or whatever) adds a new API call upstream and it's added without intent to the sandbox by simply doing an update where nobody has thought to disable it.Another way of looking at this is Gradle isn't being compiled into Java bytecode and run in the same environment as the IDE (sandboxed or otherwise). That is inherently riskier.
comments.content_cn: 该特定漏洞依赖于将require函数传递至某个作用域，从而允许加载并执行任意代码。这正是我常说的黑名单方法——你在沙箱中声明某些功能因可能导致逃逸而禁止使用。另一种方式是白名单方法，即不直接禁用危险功能，而是仅启用所需功能。因此像Gradle或Maven这类构建系统（两者本质相同）仅允许访问有限的原始操作集，它并非加载整个JVM及所有Java核心库后再列出所有禁止使用的功能。您看出区别了吗？至少当虚拟机（或其他环境）在上游新增API调用时，若更新过程中无人考虑禁用该功能，黑名单方法就会因新增接口无意间被纳入沙箱而失效。另一种理解角度是：Gradle并未被编译成Java字节码，也未在与IDE相同的环境（无论是否沙箱化）中运行，这本身就存在更高风险。

posts.title: Why does SSH send 100 packets per keystroke?
posts.author: eieio
posts.title_cn: "为什么SSH每次按键会发送100个数据包？"
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕SSH协议中每个击键发送大量数据包的现象展开。核心话题是2023年SSH引入的击键计时混淆机制，该机制通过发送大量干扰数据包来防止攻击者通过分析击键间隔推测输入内容。

社区观点呈现明显分歧。有用户支持这一安全改进，指出击键时序分析曾是真实威胁，混淆机制能有效防御；也有用户质疑其性能开销，认为每秒数千数据包消耗20%CPU核心资源的效率过低，反映出代码性能优化不足。讨论中提到，虽然该功能可客户端禁用，但有用户强烈警告在生产环境中禁用可能带来安全风险。

共识在于认可击键时序分析的安全威胁确实存在。主要争议集中在实现方式上：一方认为安全优先值得性能代价，另一方则认为当前实现效率低下，应寻求更优方案。还有用户指出AI辅助调试工具在讨论中被提及，但其实际效用和表达方式也引发了一些争议。

It was readable and explained the problem the OP was encountering and proposed solutions well.

或者你也可以采用任播技术，将SSH会话终止在多个基于地理位置的逆向代理服务器上，然后通过为低延迟优化的内部网络链路将数据包转发到应用服务器。大型企业已经在HTTP over TLS上采用类似方案来实现DDoS防护并降低TLS端到端延迟。当然这会增加成本（因为需要部署逆向代理），但能快速获得可接受的延迟和基础DDoS防护，并且可以独立于主应用逻辑尝试不同的连接方案。

虽然很难估算这种情况下SSH2逆向代理会增加多少延迟，但实际延迟可能比想象中要低。想到让Claude随意处理我的加密实现方案，这大概是我近期听过最可怕的事情（尽管libnss本身问题重重，这种情况下可能也不会更糟了）。不过我很欣赏这篇技术分析，它清晰易读，准确阐述了原帖作者遇到的问题，并给出了很好的解决方案建议。

comments.content: Haven't heard of TCP_CORK, very interesting.For people who don't feel like googling it:1. You TCP_CORK a socket2. You put data into it and the kernel buffers it3. If you uncork the socket, or if the buffer hits MSS, the kernel sends the packetBasically, the kernel waits until it has a full packet worth of data, or until you say you don't have any more data to send, and then it sends. comments.content_cn: 没听说过TCP_CORK，很有意思。给懒得搜索的人解释一下：1. 给套接字设置TCP_CORK标志；2. 向其中写入数据时内核会进行缓冲；3. 当取消CORK标志或缓冲区达到MSS大小时，内核才会发送数据包。本质上，内核会等待直到积累足够组成完整数据包的数据量，或者直到你明确表示没有更多数据要发送时才会发出数据。这有点像极端的TCP_YESDELAY机制。我是在https://catonmat.net/tcp-cork这个网站上了解到这些的。

comments.author: Veserv
comments.content: I do not know where people get the idea that encryption is that slow. Standard AES hardware acceleration instructions do ~25 Gbps per core (on a 2023 CPU) which is ~50x that rate [1]. I have heard modern cores can do ~40-50 Gbps, but I have not been able to find any independent benchmarks of that. Even the Intel i5-2500, a CPU from 2011, averages ~10 Gbps which is ~20x that rate. Even unaccelerated encryption can do ~2-5 Gbps in pure software which is 4-10x the SSH rate.And in this situation, the amount of encrypted payload in each packet is 36 bytes which is ~40x less than a full packet of ~1500 bytes. You would almost surely hit packet per second limits before you hit payload throughput limits at these small sizes.Encryption is slow when compared to data throughput you can get with a properly designed transport stack, but that is because it is in comparison to 100 Gbps per core even with no hardware offload. Anything less than ~10 Gbps/1 million packets per second (ignoring other bottlenecks, so only the software transport is the limit) is not merely unoptimized, it is pessimized.[1] https://calomel.org/aesni_ssl_performance.html
comments.content_cn:
我不明白人们为何会认为加密速度如此之慢。标准的AES硬件加速指令每核心（在2023年的CPU上）可达到约25 Gbps，这大约是那个速度的50倍[1]。我听说现代核心能达到约40-50 Gbps，但尚未找到独立的基准测试来证实。即使是2011年的Intel i5-2500 CPU，平均也能达到约10 Gbps，大约是那个速度的20倍。即使是没有硬件加速的纯软件加密，也能达到约2-5 Gbps，是SSH速度的4到10倍。

在这种情况下，每个数据包中的加密负载仅为36字节，比完整数据包的约1500字节少了约40倍。在这种小尺寸下，几乎肯定会在达到负载吞吐量限制之前，先达到每秒数据包数量的限制。

与设计良好的传输栈所能达到的数据吞吐量相比，加密确实较慢，但这是因为即使没有硬件卸载，每核心的吞吐量也能达到100 Gbps。任何低于约10 Gbps/每秒100万个数据包的速度（忽略其他瓶颈，仅以软件传输为限）不仅未优化，简直是过于悲观了。

[1] https://calomel.org/aesni_ssl_performance.html

有一种观点认为，如果：  
- 你正在监听设备之间的SSH会话  
- 并且你知道连接上使用的协议（即他们在讨论什么）  
- 且该协议具有合理的可预测性  
那么你就能获得足够多的明文信息，从而开始提取有关密码和密钥的信息。  
这无疑是一种非平凡的攻击手段，但完全可行。特别是当存在第三方来源（例如参与者提供的同一协议下的其他服务）泄露了参与者的一定可观察状态时。

comments.author: xenadu02
comments.content: I assume the problem, such as it is, relates to the fact that a real human typing in 20-50ms would generate a few characters at most but a program could generate gobs of data. So automatically you know what packets to watch. Then you know if there were more the likely keys were in set X, while if there were fewer the likely keys were in set Y.So a clock doesn't solve the problem. The amount of data sent on each clock pulse also tells you something about what was sent.The Chaff packets already fire on a timer. They inject random extra fake keystrokes so you can't tell how many keystrokes were actually made. The only other way I can think of to solve that is by using a step function: Send one larger packet (fragmented or the same number of individual packets) on each clock pulse if the actual data is less than some N where N is the maximum keystrokes ever recorded with some margin. Effectively almost every clock pulse will be one packet (or set of packets) of identical size. Of course if you do that then you'll end up consuming more data over time than sending random amounts of packets.
comments.content_cn:
我认为问题的关键在于：真人打字时20-50毫秒内最多输入几个字符，而程序却能生成大量数据。因此你自然知道该监控哪些数据包。这样就能推断：若数据量较大，可能的按键属于集合X；若数据量较小，则属于集合Y。所以时钟机制并不能解决问题——每个时钟脉冲发送的数据量本身就会泄露信息。

现有的干扰数据包已采用定时发送机制，通过注入随机虚假击键数据来掩盖真实击键次数。我能想到的另一种解决方案是采用阶梯函数：当实际数据量小于设定阈值N时（N需留有余量地大于历史最大击键数），每个时钟脉冲固定发送一个较大数据包（可分片或拆分为相同数量的独立数据包）。这样几乎每个时钟脉冲都会发送尺寸完全一致的数据包（或数据包组）。当然，这种做法的代价是长期来看会比随机发送消耗更多数据流量。
