comments.author: convolvatron
comments.content: its not really a question of 'udp performs better'. in tcp we have to live to head-of-line blocking on losses and congestion control. if you don't care about receiving every packet, but only the most recent, then udp is a good choice.running without congestion control means that you avoid slowstart. but at a certain rate you run into  poorly defined 'fairness' issues where you can easily negatively impact other flows. past that point, you can actually self-interfere and cause excessive losses for yourself.quic uses congestion control, but uses latency estimates and variance as a signal to back off. it still imposes an ordering on a per-stream basis. so it might not be ideal either.sctp has a mode which supports reliable and unordered, which might be something to considerso really - if you care about latency and have a different reliability model, its worth unpacking all these considerations and using them to select your transport layer or even consider writing a minimal one yourself
comments.content_cn: 这并非“UDP性能更好”的问题。在TCP中，我们必须面对丢包时的队头阻塞和拥塞控制。如果您不关心接收每个数据包，而只关注最新数据，那么UDP是个不错的选择。不使用拥塞控制意味着避免慢启动，但在达到一定速率时，您会遇到定义模糊的“公平性”问题，可能轻易对其他数据流造成负面影响。超过该临界点后，您甚至可能产生自我干扰并导致自身数据包过度丢失。QUIC采用拥塞控制，但以延迟估计和方差作为退避信号。它仍会在每个流上强制排序，因此可能也不是最理想的方案。SCTP具有支持可靠传输和无序传输的模式，或许值得考虑。所以实际上——如果您关注延迟且拥有不同的可靠性模型，有必要逐一剖析这些因素，据此选择传输层协议，甚至可以考虑自行编写最简化的传输方案。

posts.title: Show HN: isometric.nyc – giant isometric pixel art map of NYC
posts.content: Hey HN! I wanted to share something I built over the last few weeks: isometric.nyc is a massive isometric pixel art map of NYC, built with nano banana and coding agents.I didn't write a single line of code.Of course no-code doesn't mean no-engineering. This project took a lot more manual labor than I'd hoped!I wrote a deep dive on the workflow and some thoughts about the future of AI coding and creativity:http://cannoneyed.com/projects/isometric-nyc
posts.author: cannoneyed
posts.title_cn: "Show HN: isometric.nyc – 纽约市巨型等距像素艺术地图"
posts.content_cn: 嘿，HN的各位！我想分享一个我过去几周搭建的项目：isometric.nyc 是一个巨大的纽约市等距像素艺术地图，使用nano banana和编码智能体构建。我没有写一行代码。当然，无代码并不意味着无工程。这个项目比我预想的要耗费更多手工劳动！我写了一篇深度文章，探讨了工作流程以及对AI编码和创造力未来的一些思考：http://cannoneyed.com/projects/isometric-nyc
posts.abstract:
该HackerNews帖子展示了用户创建的纽约市巨型等距像素艺术地图项目isometric.nyc，核心话题围绕AI辅助创作工具在艺术与工程实践中的应用及争议。作者强调项目完全使用nano banana和编码代理实现零代码开发，但指出无代码不等于无工程，实际投入了大量手工劳动。

社区讨论呈现多元观点：有人认为该项目呈现效果惊艳，比传统卫星地图更清晰直观；也有用户指出其并非真正像素艺术，AI生成痕迹明显且缺乏手工质感。讨论中提到，部分用户肯定AI工具降低了创意实现门槛，使原本停留在构想阶段的项目得以落地；同时存在分歧，一方认为AI解放了重复性劳动，另一方则强调传统手工创作的价值不可替代，并以1964年百人手工建造纽约全景模型为例对比AI时代单人创作模式。

普遍共识是作者详细记录工作流程的博客文章具有参考价值，帮助读者理解AI编码的当前局限。争议焦点集中于AI生成内容是否算真正艺术创作，以及工具效率提升与艺术本质之间的平衡问题。

comments.author: crazygringo
comments.content: I just want to say this isn't just amazing -- it's my new favorite map of NYC.It's genuinely astonishing how much clearer this is than a traditional satellite map -- how it has just the right amount of complexity. I'm looking at areas I've spent a lot of time in, and getting an even better conceptual understanding of the physical layout than I've ever been able to get from satellite (technically airplane) images. This hits the perfect "sweet spot" of detail with clear "cartoon" coloring.I see a lot of criticism here that this isn't "pixel art", so maybe there's some better term to use. I don't know what to call this precise style -- it's almost pixel art without the pixels? -- but I love it. Serious congratulations.
comments.content_cn:
我只想说这不仅仅是令人惊叹——它已成为我最喜欢的纽约地图。比传统卫星地图清晰得多，复杂程度恰到好处，实在令人震撼。看着那些我曾长时间停留的区域，我对实体布局的概念理解甚至比从卫星（技术上说是航拍）图像中获得的更深入。这种细节处理达到了完美的“甜点”平衡，搭配清晰的“卡通”配色。

我看到很多批评说这不是“像素艺术”，或许该用更准确的术语。我不知道该如何定义这种精确的风格——它像是没有像素的像素艺术？——但我非常喜欢。衷心表示祝贺。

comments.author: cannoneyed
comments.content: Author here, and to reiterate another reply - all of the critique of "pixel art" is completely fair. Aesthetically and philosophically, what AI does for "pixel art" is very off. And once you see the AI you can't really unsee it.But I didn't want to call it a "SimCity" map, though that's really the vibe/inspiration I wanted to capture, because that implies a lot of other things, so I used the term "pixel art" even though I figured it might get a lot of (valid) pushback...In general, labels and genres are really hard - "techno" to a deep head in Berlin is very different than "techno" to my cousins. This issue has always been fraught, because context and meaning and technique are all tangled up in these labels which are so important to some but so easily ignored by others. And those questions are even harder in the age of AI where the machine just gobbles up everything.But regardless, it was a fun project! And to me at least it's better to just make cool ambitious things in good faith and understand that art by definition is meaningful and therefore makes people feel things from love to anger to disgust to fascination.
comments.content_cn: 作者在此重申另一个回复——所有对“像素艺术”的批评都完全合理。从美学和哲学角度看，AI处理“像素艺术”的方式确实很不协调。一旦你见识过AI生成的作品，那种印象就很难抹去。不过，我并不想称它为“模拟城市”风格的地图，尽管这确实是我想要捕捉的感觉和灵感，因为那会引发许多其他联想，所以我用了“像素艺术”这个词，尽管我料到可能会招来不少（合理的）反对意见……总的来说，标签和流派确实很难界定——对柏林的资深电子乐迷而言，“科技舞曲”的含义与我表亲理解的“科技舞曲”可能截然不同。这个问题一直充满争议，因为背景、意义和技巧都纠缠在这些标签中，对某些人至关重要，对另一些人却轻易被忽视。而在AI时代，机器囫囵吞下一切，这些问题变得更加复杂。但无论如何，这是一个有趣的项目！至少对我来说，怀着诚意去创作酷炫而有野心的作品更好，要理解艺术本质上是有意义的，因此会引发人们从喜爱到愤怒、从厌恶到着迷的各种感受。

comments.author: Tiberium
comments.content: Great project! Just wanted to talk about the "/ The edit problem" section in the blog post - it's almost entirely false. Inpainting (when you provide a mask) has existed for years, and for good edit models (such as Nano Banana Pro) you can annotate the image, and it'll only edit one part, keeping the rest almost entirely consistent. The same goes for other top editing models like Flux 2, Seedream 4.5 and so on.Transparency also exists, e.g. GPT Image does it, and Nano Banana Pro should have it supported soon as well.
comments.content_cn: 很出色的项目！不过想谈谈博客中“/编辑问题”这个部分——这部分内容几乎完全不符合事实。遮罩修复（当你提供遮罩时）技术已经存在多年，对于优秀的编辑模型（比如Nano Banana Pro），你可以对图像进行标注，它只会编辑特定部分，同时保持其余部分几乎完全一致。其他顶级编辑模型如Flux 2、Seedream 4.5等也是如此。透明度功能同样存在，例如GPT Image已实现该功能，Nano Banana Pro预计很快也会支持。

comments.author: blintz
comments.content: I was most surprised by the fact that it only took 40 examples for a Qwen finetune to match the style and quality of (interactively tuned) Nano Banana. Certainly the end result does not look like the stock output of open-source image generation models.I wonder if for almost any bulk inference / generation task, it will generally be dramatically cheaper to (use fancy expensive model to generate examples, perhaps interactively with refinements) -> (fine tune smaller open-source model) -> (run bulk task).

comments.author: anonymous908213
comments.content: That quote seriously rubs me the wrong way. "Dragging little boxes around" in a DAW is creative, it constitutes the entire process of composing electronic music. You are notating what notes to play, when and for how long they play, what instrument plays them, and any modifications to the default sound of that instrument. Is writing sheet music tedious? Sure, it can be, when the speed of notating by hand can't keep up with the speed your brain is thinking through ideas. But being tedious is not mutually exclusive with being creative despite the attempt to explicitly contrast them as such, and the solution to the process of notating your creativity being tedious is not "randomly generate a bunch of notes and instruments that have little relation with the ones you're thinking of". This excerpt supposes that generative AI lets you automate the tedious part while keeping "the quality of your decisions", but it doesn't keep your decisions, it generates its own "decisions" from a broad, high-level prompt and your role is reduced to merely making decisions about whether or not you like the content generated, which is not creativity.
comments.content_cn: 那段引述实在让我感到不适。在数字音频工作站中"拖拽小方块"本身就是富有创造性的行为，这构成了电子音乐创作的全部过程。你正在记录要演奏的音符、演奏时机与时长、使用的乐器，以及对乐器默认音色的各种调整。谱写乐谱繁琐吗？当然可能，当手写记谱的速度跟不上大脑构思的节奏时确实如此。但繁琐与创造性并非互斥关系——尽管原文试图将二者对立起来。解决创作记录过程繁琐的方案，绝不是"随机生成一堆与你构思关联甚微的音符和乐器"。这段摘录假设生成式人工智能能自动处理繁琐环节同时保留"你的决策质量"，但实际上它并未保留你的决策，而是根据宽泛的高层次提示生成自己的"决策"，你的角色被简化为仅仅判断是否喜欢生成的内容，这根本算不上创造性。

comments.author: NAR8789
comments.content:
I think the core idea in "masking" is to provide adjacent pixel art tiles as part of the input when rendering a new tile from photo reference. So part of the input is literal boundary conditions on the output for the new tile.Reference image from the article:
https://cannoneyed.com/img/projects/isometric-nyc/training_d...You have to zoom in, but here the inputs on the left are mixed pixel art / photo textures. The outputs on the right are seamless pixel art.Later on he talks about 2x2 squares of four tiles each as input and having trouble automating input selection to avoid seams. So with his 512x512 tiles, he's actually sending in 1024x1024 inputs. You can avoid seams if every new tile can "see" all its already-generated neighbors.You get a seam if you generate a new tile next to an old tile but that old tile is not input to the infill agorithm. The new tile can't see that boundary, and the style will probably not match.
comments.content_cn:
我认为“遮罩”的核心思想在于：当根据照片参考渲染新图块时，将相邻的像素艺术图块作为输入的一部分。因此，部分输入内容实际上构成了新图块输出的字面边界条件。文章参考图：
https://cannoneyed.com/img/projects/isometric-nyc/training_d...（需放大查看）图中左侧输入是像素艺术与照片纹理的混合体，右侧输出则是无缝衔接的像素艺术。

后文提到采用2x2的四图块方阵作为输入，但在自动选择输入以避免接缝方面遇到了困难。由于他的图块尺寸为512x512，实际输入的是1024x1024的区域。如果每个新生成的图块都能“看到”所有已生成的相邻图块，就能避免接缝问题。

如果在旧图块旁生成新图块时，旧图块未被纳入填充算法的输入范围，就会产生接缝。新图块无法感知该边界，其风格很可能无法匹配。

posts.title: Qwen3-TTS family is now open sourced: Voice design, clone, and generation
posts.author: Palmik
posts.title_cn: Qwen3-TTS系列现已开源：语音设计、克隆与生成
posts.abstract: 该帖子讨论了通义千问开源Qwen3-TTS语音模型系列，核心话题围绕其语音设计、克隆与生成功能的应用与影响。社区观点呈现明显分歧：一方面，有用户积极评价其技术表现，认为部分语音克隆效果优于11labs等现有服务，且在有声书等领域有实用潜力；也有用户指出实际测试中语音克隆效果可能不稳定，例如用特朗普语音片段尝试时效果不佳。另一方面，不少用户表达了对技术滥用的担忧，认为高质量语音合成与图像生成结合可能加剧深度伪造风险，社会需警惕屏幕后内容的真实性，甚至有人讽刺地提及老年人可能因此更容易受骗。讨论中还提到技术细节问题，如本地部署方法及示例中口音准确性的小瑕疵。整体而言，社区虽认可技术进步，但对伦理与社会风险存在显著忧虑。

posts.title: 30 Years of ReactOS
posts.author: Mark_Jansen
posts.title_cn: ReactOS 30 年历程
posts.abstract:
该帖子围绕ReactOS项目30周年展开讨论，核心话题是这一开源Windows兼容操作系统的意义与前景。社区普遍认可ReactOS作为逆向工程的卓越成就，认为它在未参考原始设计的情况下重建Windows系统具有极高技术价值，许多用户对其开发者表示敬佩。

讨论中主要观点存在分歧：有人认为ReactOS在哲学层面具有重要意义，但实际应用面临挑战，需与Windows 11、Linux+Wine等方案竞争；也有用户指出ReactOS与Wine项目深度协同，可能比Linux更易用。部分观点视其为纯工程探索项目，肯定其存在价值，但认为Wine/Proton在跨平台运行Windows软件方面更实用。

关于未来发展，讨论中提到AI辅助编程可能加速项目进展，有用户期待AI填补代码缺失。此外，有声音希望ReactOS能在旧硬件（如XP时代设备）上焕发活力，同时也有用户调侃应继续推动“Linux桌面之年”。整体而言，社区虽对其实用性持不同看法，但一致赞赏项目的长期坚持与技术贡献。

comments.author: ch_123
comments.content: I would like to see ReactOS succeed for various reasons, mainly philosophical. On the other hand, for practical real-world use cases, it has to compete with several alternative solutions:1. Just use Windows 11. Yes, it sucks and MS occasionally breaks stuff - but at least hardware and software vendors will develop their code against Win 11 and test it. In other words, you have the highest likelihood that your computer will work as expected with contemporary Windows applications and drivers.2. Use an older version of Windows. If you want to use old hardware or software, odds are you will get the best experience with whatever version of Windows they were developed/tested against. You have to accept the lack of support for modern software, and you will need to take appropriate security measures such as not connecting it to the internet - but at the same time, it's unlikely that your Windows 98 retro gaming rig is your only computer, so that's probably an acceptable tradeoff.3. Run WINE on top of Linux (or some other mature open source operating system). This might not be a good solution for the average person, but ticks the box for people who feel strongly pro-open source, or anti-Microsoft. Since Windows compatibility is dictated by Windows' libraries and frameworks and not the kernel, compatibility is likely to be comparable to ReactOS.I am not saying that this covers every possible use case for ReactOS, but I would posit it covers enough that the majority of people who might contribute or invest into ReactOS will instead pick one of the above options and invest their time and energy elsewhere.

comments.content: Yes. The unique point of ReactOS is driver compatibility. An exercise in kernel development and reverse engineering, a project that clearly requires a high level of technical skill, but long past the window of opportunity for actual adoption. If ReactOS had been usable ten years ago, it would also have had a chance at adoption, but now it's firmly in the "purely for engineering" space.

comments.author: userulluipeste
comments.content: "ReactOS should be seen as something more like GNU Hurd. An exercise in kernel development and reverse engineering, a project that clearly requires a high level of technical skill, but long past the window of opportunity for actual adoption."I understand your angle, or rather the attempt of fitting them in the same picture, somehow. However, the differences between them far surpass the similarities. There was no meaningful user-base for Unix/Hurd so to speak of compared to NT kernel. There's no real basis to assert the "kernel development" argument for both, as one was indeed a research project whereas the other one is just clean room engineering march towards replicating an existing kernel. What ReactOS needs to succeed is to become more stable and complete (on the whole, not just the kernel). Once it will be able to do that, covering the later Windows capabilities will be just a nice-to-have thing. Considering all the criticism that current version of Windows receives, switching to a stable and functional ReactOS, at least for individual use, becomes a no-brainer. Comparatively, there's nothing similar that Hurd kernel can do to get to where Linux is now.

posts.title: Your app subscription is now my weekend project
posts.author: robteix
posts.title_cn: 你的应用订阅成了我的周末项目
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕“用个人周末项目替代付费订阅应用”展开，核心话题是探讨在AI辅助编程（vibecoding）兴起的背景下，用户自行开发工具替代商业订阅服务的可行性与价值。社区观点多元：有人认为许多SaaS应用本应一次性付费而非订阅制，且个人开发能节省长期成本并满足定制需求；也有用户指出，为不同规模用户开发软件所需精力差异巨大，个人项目难以达到商业软件的质量与支持水平。讨论中提到，部分用户肯定AI工具（如ClaudeCode）能快速实现个性化需求，效率高于筛选现有产品；但同时有反对意见强调，软件凝结了开发者的专业知识与持续优化，付费订阅是对其价值的合理支持。共识在于，AI降低了开发门槛，使个人工具创建更便捷，但分歧集中在“时间成本与软件价值如何权衡”——一方认为自行开发更经济自主，另一方则认为专业软件值得付费以获取可靠体验与更新维护。

comments.content: Software is a manifestation of someone’s knowledge of and experience in and ideas about how a thing should work. My workflow is better because of the incremental improvements made by developer after developer year after year. comments.content:
I made the same realization two weeks ago. Posted about it here, where I rebuilt bare bones todoist with a habit tracker, goal setting and more within a few vibe coding sessions: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46633092I think that many existing apps with huge userbases will gradually lose users as the models become better and better. Their biggest advantage is that people don't like change, and thus having to e.g. export data from some tools etc. seems to be a hassle not worth $5 a month.
But as the models get better and the quality of the output will match the quality of the established SaaS but tailor the whole thing to a single user with the ability to make any change they can imagine within minutes, and perhaps deploy to Hetzner and whatnot where they could host all of those apps for a single $5 instead, the exodus will accelerate.On the other hand, new products will have a much harder time to gather a big userbase. Whenever I'll see a launch of a SaaS asking for $$$, the first question I'll ask myself will be how long it will take LLM to recreate it. And for most cases, I imagine that the time it will take to get 80% of what they have is a few vibe coding sessions (as most newcomers will probably have used LLM themselves to code it up).

posts.title: Satya Nadella: "We need to find something useful for AI"
posts.author: marcyb5st
posts.title_cn: 萨提亚·纳德拉："我们需要为AI找到有用之处"
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕微软CEO纳德拉关于“需要为AI找到有用之处”的言论展开，核心话题是探讨当前AI（尤其是大语言模型）的实际效用与市场宣传之间的落差。社区普遍认同AI在某些场景（如快速问答）能提升便利性，但对生产力的实质性提升幅度存在分歧。

有人认为AI工具（如ChatGPT）在信息检索上比传统搜索更便捷，但节省的时间对整体生产力影响有限；也有用户指出，像Copilot这类集成办公的AI功能令人失望，不值得高昂订阅费。讨论中提到，部分观点将当前AI热潮视为VC驱动的技术泡沫，强调技术本身缺乏明确的“产品-市场契合点”。

争议点集中在AI的实际应用领域：一方面，有观点认为AI可能像电子表格革新会计行业一样，在用户具备足够专业知识引导和验证的前提下成为实用工具；另一方面，用户对AI“颠覆医疗等行业”的宣传表示困惑，认为其具体定义与实现路径并不清晰。社区普遍观察到，非技术人群更关注AI生成内容的低质量（“信息糟粕”）及其泛滥问题，这进一步加剧了对AI实用性的质疑。

comments.author: MadDemon
comments.content: LLMs and their capabilities are very impressive and definitely useful. The productivity gains often seem to be smaller than intuitively expected though. For example, using ChatGPT to get a response to a random question like "How do I do XYZ" is much more convenient than googling it, but the time savings are often not that relevant for your overall productivity. Before LLMs you were usually already able to find the information quickly and even a 10x speed up does not really have too much of an impact on your overall productivity, because the time it took was already negligible.
comments.content_cn: 大型语言模型及其能力令人印象深刻，无疑具有实用价值。然而，其带来的效率提升往往比直观预期的要小。例如，使用ChatGPT回答“如何实现XYZ”这类随机问题，确实比通过谷歌搜索更方便，但节省的时间对整体工作效率影响并不显著。因为在大型语言模型出现之前，人们通常已经能够快速找到所需信息，即使速度提升十倍，对整体工作效率的实际影响也有限，毕竟原先耗费的时间本就微不足道。

comments.author: palmotea
comments.content: > For example, using ChatGPT to get a response to a random question like "How do I do XYZ" is much more convenient than googling it, but the time savings are often not that relevant for your overall productivity. Before LLMs you were usually already able to find the information quickly and even a 10x speed up does not really have too much of an impact on your overall productivity, because the time it took was already negligible.I'd even question that. The pre-LLM solutions were in most cases better. Searching a maintained database of curated and checked information is far better than LLM output (which is possibly bullshit).Ditto to software engineering. In software, we have things call libraries: you write the code once, test it, then you trust it and can use it as many times as you want forever for free. Why use LLM generated code when you have a library? And if you're asking for anything complex, you're probably just getting a plagiarized and bastardized version of some library anyway.The only thing where LLMs shine is a kind of simple, lazy "mash this up so I don't have to think about it" cases. And sometimes it might be better to just do it yourself and develop your own skills instead of use an LLM.
comments.content_cn: 例如，使用ChatGPT获取诸如“如何做XYZ”这类随机问题的答案，比通过谷歌搜索方便得多，但节省的时间通常对整体工作效率影响不大。在大型语言模型出现之前，人们通常已经能够快速找到所需信息，即使速度提升十倍，对整体工作效率的实际影响也有限，因为原本花费的时间就微不足道。我甚至对此表示质疑。在大多数情况下，大型语言模型之前的解决方案更为优越。搜索经过维护、精心整理和核验的信息数据库，远比大型语言模型的输出更可靠（后者可能充满谬误）。软件工程领域也是如此。在软件开发中，我们有所谓的库：代码只需编写一次，经过测试后便可信任，并能够永久免费重复使用。既然已有现成的库，为何还要使用大型语言模型生成的代码？如果你需要处理复杂任务，大型语言模型给出的很可能只是某个库的抄袭版或拙劣改编版。大型语言模型唯一擅长的，是那些简单、偷懒的“拼凑一下，省得我动脑”的场景。有时，亲自动手并提升自身技能，可能比依赖大型语言模型更为可取。

comments.author: Gazoche
comments.content: Evangelists keep insisting that healthcare is one of the things that AI will revolutionize in the coming years, but I just don't get it. To me it's not even clear what they mean by "AI" in this context (and I'm not convinced it's clear to them either).If they mean "machine learning", then sure there are application in cancer detection and the like, but development there has been moving at a steady pace for decades and has nothing to do with the current hype wave of GenAI, so there's no reason to assume it's suddenly going to go exponential. I used to work in that field and I'm confident it's not going to change overnight: progress there is slow not because of the models, but because data is sparse and noisy, labels are even sparser and noisier, deployment procedures are rigid and legal compliance is a nightmare.If they mean "generative AI", then how is that supposed to work exactly? Asking LLMs for medical diagnosis is no better than asking "the Internet at large". They only return the most statistically likely output given their training corpus (that corpus being the Internet as a whole), so it's more likely your diagnosis will be based on a random Reddit comment that the LLMs has ingested somewhere, than an actual medical paper.The only plausible applications I can think of are tasks such as summarizing papers, acting as augmented search engines for datasets and papers, or maybe automating some menial administrative tasks. Useful, for sure, but not revolutionary.
comments.content_cn:
鼓吹者们不断强调医疗健康将是人工智能在未来几年彻底变革的领域之一，但我实在无法理解。首先，我甚至不清楚他们在这个语境下所说的"人工智能"具体指什么（而且我怀疑他们自己也未必清楚）。如果指的是"机器学习"，那确实在癌症检测等领域已有应用，但相关技术数十年来一直稳步发展，与当前生成式人工智能的热潮并无关联，因此没有理由认为它会突然呈现指数级突破。我曾在该领域工作过，确信这不会一夜之间改变：进展缓慢并非因为模型本身，而是由于数据稀缺且噪声多，标注数据更为稀少且质量参差，部署流程僵化，法律合规更是噩梦。

如果指的是"生成式人工智能"，那具体如何运作呢？向大语言模型咨询医疗诊断，效果并不比"随便上网查"更好。它们只是根据训练语料库（即整个互联网内容）返回统计上最可能的输出结果，因此你的诊断更可能基于模型偶然吸收的某个随机Reddit评论，而非真正的医学论文。

我能想到唯一合理的应用场景，无非是总结论文、作为数据集和论文的增强型搜索引擎，或者自动化一些琐碎的行政任务。这些确实有用，但绝对谈不上革命性。

posts.author: roywashere
posts.title_cn: JPEG XL 测试页面
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕JPEG XL图像格式的测试页面展开，核心话题是JPEG XL在不同浏览器中的兼容性与性能表现。有人认为JPEG XL命名不够理想，未能体现其轻量高效的特点；也有用户指出该格式在Firefox中即使启用标志仍无法显示，但在基于WebKit的浏览器（如Epiphany）或特定分支（如Orion、Ladybird）中运行良好。讨论中提到Chrome从v145版本开始支持JPEG XL，并可通过扩展程序增强兼容性。用户对测试方法提出疑问，认为仅使用合成图像而未涵盖真实照片类别可能影响评估全面性。社区普遍认同JPEG XL在技术上有优势，但对其跨浏览器支持仍存在分歧，部分用户认为浏览器兼容性是目前主要障碍。

comments.author: gcr
comments.content: One thing I like about JPEG-XL is that it supports all kinds of weird image formats.For example, I used to work with depth data a lot, which is best expressed as monochrome 16-bit floating point images. Previously, TIFF was the only format that supported this. Many shops would instead save depth images as UINT16 .PNG files, where the raw pixel intensity maps to the camera distance in mm. The problem with this is that pixels more than 65.535 meters away aren't representable. (Hot take: I personally think this is one reason why nobody studies depth estimation for outdoor scenes.)JPEG-XL supports more weird combinations here, e.g. storing greyscale float32 images (with alpha even! you can store sparse depth maps without needing a separate mask!)It's like, uniquely suited to these sorts of 3D scene understanding challenges and I really hope people adopt the format for more scientific applications.
comments.content_cn: 我喜欢JPEG-XL的一点是它支持各种奇怪的图像格式。例如，我过去经常处理深度数据，这类数据最适合用单通道16位浮点图像表示。以前只有TIFF格式支持这种类型。许多工作室会改用UINT16格式的PNG文件保存深度图像，原始像素强度对应以毫米为单位的相机距离。这样做的问题在于超过65.535米的像素无法被表示。（个人观点：我认为这是没有人研究户外场景深度估计的原因之一。）JPEG-XL支持更多特殊组合，例如存储灰度float32图像（甚至支持alpha通道！你可以存储稀疏深度图而无需单独的遮罩！）它似乎特别适合这类3D场景理解挑战，我真心希望人们能在更多科学应用中使用这种格式。

comments.content: Jake Archibald has an excellent post about progressive image rendering, including some metrics on JPEG XL compared to AVIF[0].> "I was also surprised to see that, in Safari, JPEG XL takes 150% longer (as in 2.5x) to decode vs an equivalent AVIF. That's 17ms longer on my M4 Pro. Apple hardware tends to be high-end, but this could still be significant. This isn't related to progressive rendering; the decoder is just slow. There's some suggestion that the Apple implementation is running on a single core, so maybe there's room for improvement.> JPEG XL support in Safari actually comes from the underlying OS rather than the browser. My guess is that Apple is considering using JPEG XL for iPhone photo storage rather than HEIC, and JPEG XL's inclusion in the browser is a bit of an afterthought. I'm just guessing though.> The implementation that was in Chromium behind a flag did support progressive rendering to some degree, but it didn't render anything until ~60 kB (39% of the file). The rendering is similar to the initial JPEG rendering above, but takes much more image data to get there. This is a weakness in the decoder rather than the format itself. I'll dive into what JPEG XL is capable of shortly.> I also tested the performance of the old behind-a-flag Chromium JPEG XL decoder, and it's over 500% slower (6x) to decode than AVIF. The old behind-a-flag Firefox JPEG XL decoder is about as slow as the Safari decoder. It's not fair to judge the performance of experimental unreleased things, but I was kinda hoping one of these would suggest that the Safari implementation was an outlier.> I thought that "fast decoding" was one of the selling points of JPEG XL over AVIF, but now I'm not so sure.> We have a Rust implementation of JPEG XL underway in Firefox, but performance needs to get a lot better before we can land it."[0]: https://jakearchibald.com/2025/present-and-future-of-progres...

posts.title: Design Thinking Books (2024)
posts.author: rrm1977
posts.title_cn: 设计思维书籍（2024）
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕“设计思维”书籍推荐展开，核心话题是探讨设计思维的本质、价值及其在不同领域的应用。社区观点多元，存在明显分歧。

有人认为设计思维是试图在非专业领域获取影响力的工具，类似于用户体验中的数据科学，并批评其可能过于简化实际问题。也有用户指出设计思维本质上是“思考”本身，只是在不同领域（如建筑、软件、图形设计）有具体的方法论体现，不应被过度神化。讨论中提到多本经典书籍，如《设计心理学》《设计原本》《点石成金》等，这些作品被普遍视为理解设计原则的重要参考，尤其关注如何连接人类行为与物/软件的设计本质。

然而，对于设计思维的范畴存在对立看法：一方认为它是系统思维的子集，批评其分类可能造成不必要的分割；另一方则强调其跨学科的通用价值。共识在于，优秀的设计应基于对人类行为的深刻理解，且实际经验与经典著作比抽象方法论更重要。

comments.author: bsoles

Nobody wants another Agile(TM) process imposed on software developers (in my particular case) that attempts to turn developers into factory line workers.

comments.author: gond
comments.content:
Please don’t use Design Thinking.Design Thinking is a subset of Systems Thinking (this is the polite interpretation). 
Design Thinking does with its sole existence what Systems Thinking tried to avoid: Another category to put stuff into, divide and conquer. It is an over-simplified version of the original theories.Better: Jump directly to Systems Thinking, Cybernetics and Systems Theory (and if measurements are more your thing, even try System Dynamics).I can only recommend that anyone interested in this topic take a look at the work of one of the masters of Systems Thinking, Russel Ackoff:https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=9p6vrULecFIThis talk from 1991 is several dozen books heavily condensed into one hour.(Russell Ackoff is considered one of the founders of Operations Research and ironically came to be regarded an apostate as he tried to reform the field he co-founded. He subsequently became a prominent figure of Systems Thinking)My 2c. I'll show myself out.
comments.content_cn:
请不要使用设计思维。设计思维是系统思维的一个分支（这是比较客气的解读）。设计思维的存在本身恰恰做了系统思维试图避免的事：又创造出一个分类来划分事物、分而治之。它是对原始理论的过度简化。

更好的做法是：直接转向系统思维、控制论和系统理论（如果你更偏好量化分析，甚至可以尝试系统动力学）。我只能建议对此话题感兴趣的人看看系统思维大师之一拉塞尔·阿克夫的作品：https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=9p6vrULecFI
这场1991年的演讲将数十本书的内容浓缩在一小时内。（拉塞尔·阿克夫被认为是运筹学创始人之一，讽刺的是，当他试图改革自己共同创立的领域时，却被视为异端。后来他成为系统思维的重要代表人物）

以上是我的个人见解。我先退场了。

As we know the exact point of a strong password is that it will not be in a rainbow table.Of course the original version is pretty old but I picked up the latest revised version. Still some interesting insights and I haven't given up on the book quite yet but it's been a ton of theory and a lot of terminology so far.
comments.content_cn: 我是一名开发者，最近开始阅读《设计心理学》这本书，试图培养更多设计思维。大家都盛赞它如同设计界的圣经。目前我读了大约80页，感觉内容非常学术化且不太实用，有时得出的结论与现实相去甚远，甚至令人担忧，比如作者认为强密码并不重要，因为一旦密码不可避免地泄露，总可以通过彩虹表破解（作者没有使用这个具体术语）。但众所周知，强密码的意义恰恰在于它不会被收录在彩虹表中。当然，原版书年代较为久远，我读的是最新的修订版。书中仍有一些有趣的见解，我也没有完全放弃阅读，但到目前为止，理论内容过多，术语也相当繁杂。

comments.author: HillRat
comments.content: Design thinking, at least in its formal STS approach, is essentially applied sociology; it's about using various toolkits to build a sufficient understanding of a domain from the "inside out" (using desk and field research) so that you can design valuable experiences that build upon the expertise of those actually inside the domain. In this, it's a bridge between UX/product and users/stakeholders (technical stakeholders are admittedly too often an afterthought, but that's a process problem). If anyone comes in and attempts to blindly shove workshops at you without first conducting in-depth research, interviews, and field studies in your domain, then they are (without resorting to the One True Scotsman) not doing design thinking, they're doing cargo-cult brainstorming. (It's also a process orthogonal to agile development, since by definition it's a linear process that needs to be conducted prior to developing the actual product features and requirements.)The books and papers the OP cites are solid (Rittel and Webber, Buchanan, etc., though TRIZ, I think, is rather oversold), but in my experience the problem with most design thinking practitioners is that they aren't qualified sociologists and ethnographers, so a lot of design thinking is basically a reinvention of the last century of sociological middle-range theory and ethnographic principles, without being strongly informed by either, likely due to the field's foundation in early software requirements studies.
comments.content_cn: 设计思维，至少在其正式的科学、技术与社会研究路径中，本质上是应用社会学；它关乎运用多种工具包，通过“由内而外”的方式（利用案头研究和实地调研）对某个领域建立充分理解，从而能够基于该领域内实际专家的专业知识，设计出有价值的体验。在此意义上，它成为用户体验/产品与用户/利益相关者之间的桥梁（技术利益相关者确实常被事后考虑，但这是流程问题）。如果有人未经事先在您所在领域进行深入调研、访谈和实地研究，就盲目地向您强行推行研讨会，那么他们（无需诉诸“真正苏格兰人”谬误）并非在进行设计思维，而是在进行货船崇拜式的头脑风暴。（这也是一种与敏捷开发正交的流程，因为从定义上讲，它是一种线性过程，需要在开发实际产品特性和需求之前进行。）原帖引用的书籍和论文扎实可靠（如里特尔与韦伯、布坎南等，不过我认为TRIZ理论被过度吹捧了），但根据我的经验，大多数设计思维实践者的问题在于，他们并非合格的社会学家和人种志学者，因此许多设计思维基本上是对上世纪社会学中层理论和人种志原则的重新发明，却未充分汲取这两者的精髓，这可能源于该领域早期软件需求研究的基础。

comments.author: jasonhong
comments.content:
I've used The Design of Everyday Things in many classes I teach. I would agree that it's not practical, but that's not its goal. Instead, it gives you frameworks for thinking about things as well as vocabulary for talking about those things.Off the top of my head, some of the key ideas include:* Affordances, that objects should have (often visual) cues that give hints as to how to use things
* Mental models, that every design has three different models, namely system implementation, design model, and user model, and that the design model and user model should try to match each other
* Gulf of Evaluation (the gap between the current system state and people's understanding of it) and Gulf of Execution (the gap between what people want the system to do and how to use the system to do it)
* Kinds of Errors and how to design to prevent and recover from them, e.g. slips (chose the right action but accidentally did the wrong thing, e.g. fat finger) vs mistakes (chose the wrong action to do)What's particularly useful about Norman's book is that these key ideas apply for all kinds of user interfaces, from command-line to GUI to voice-only to AR/VR to AI chatbot. I'd encourage you to think about this book in this kind of framing, that it gives you general frameworks for reasoning and talking about UX problems rather than specific practical solutions.
comments.content_cn:
我在多门课程教学中都使用过《设计心理学》这本书。我同意它并不侧重实践性，但这并非其目的。这本书的价值在于提供思考问题的框架和讨论这些问题的术语体系。凭记忆列举几个核心概念：

* 可供性：物品应具备（通常是视觉上的）提示线索，暗示其使用方式
* 心智模型：每个设计都包含三种不同模型——系统实现模型、设计师模型和用户模型，后两者应尽可能保持一致
* 评估鸿沟（系统当前状态与用户理解之间的差距）和执行鸿沟（用户目标与系统操作方式之间的差距）
* 错误分类及预防设计：例如失误（选对动作但误操作，如按错键）与误解（选择错误动作）

诺曼这本书特别有价值的地方在于，这些核心概念适用于所有用户界面——从命令行到图形界面，从纯语音交互到增强现实/虚拟现实，再到人工智能聊天机器人。建议你从这个角度理解本书：它提供的是思考用户体验问题的通用框架和讨论语言，而非具体的实践解决方案。

comments.author: Nemi

I have been complaining about this years.Ok this will be a tangent, but I also take this one step farther and also talk about "documentation". Just for the record, I don't think documentation is all good or all bad, but it definitely can be used incorrectly and in excess. And Norman Doors and a great way to get this point across.When someone creates or installs a Norman Door by accident or out of ignorance and then realizes there is a problem, they often think "I know, I will document it!" and they add little placards to the door that says "Push/Pull" or some such. They see that this helps with a small subset of users and thinks "there, I fixed the problem, people just need to read the documentation and now it is their problem if they don't". But if you watch users of the door, a large portion will still use the door incorrectly because... people don't read documentation. If they don't read documentation, is it the users fault the door was designed incorrectly or was it the designers problem?I use this as an example for my developers on thinking before documenting troublesome code or a confusing interface to first ask "can I design this so it is less confusing?" and if so, that would usually be preferable to adding documentation "to solve the problem". 我太喜欢这个了。感谢你向我介绍"诺曼门"。我之前没意识到有人如此详细地描述过这个问题。多年来我一直在抱怨这类设计。好吧，这可能有点跑题，但我还想进一步谈谈"文档说明"。需要说明的是，我并不认为文档说明完全好或完全坏，但它确实可能被误用和过度使用。而诺曼门是阐明这个观点的绝佳例子。

当有人因疏忽或无知而创建或安装了诺曼门，随后意识到存在问题，他们往往会想"我知道了，我要加上说明文档！"于是他们在门上添加"推/拉"之类的小标牌。他们发现这能帮助一小部分用户，便认为"好了，问题解决了，现在人们只需要阅读说明文档，如果不读就是他们自己的问题了"。但如果你观察门的使用者，很大一部分人仍然会错误使用这扇门，因为...人们根本不看说明文档。如果用户不阅读说明，这到底是错误设计导致的用户过失，还是设计者的问题？

我常以此为例告诉开发人员：在为问题代码或混乱接口编写文档前，首先要思考"我能否重新设计使其更清晰易懂？"如果可以，这通常比添加文档来"解决问题"更可取。没有文档的优秀设计（无论是代码还是门）永远胜过依赖文档的糟糕设计。

posts.title: Claude Chill: Fix Claude Code's flickering in terminal
posts.author: behnamoh
posts.title_cn: Claude Chill：修复Claude代码在终端中的闪烁问题
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕Claude Code终端界面闪烁问题的修复展开。核心话题是开发者宣布已部署全新的差分渲染器以解决长期存在的显示闪烁问题，但社区反应复杂。

有人认为这是重大改进，有用户表示将立即安装测试；也有用户指出问题拖延过久，质疑Anthropic不开放源代码是因代码库混乱。讨论中提到与Codex的对比，部分用户认为Codex响应更稳定，而Claude在长时间运行后会出现卡顿。

普遍共识是闪烁问题确实影响使用体验，但社区对修复进度存在分歧：部分用户赞赏开发者的努力，另一些用户则批评公司沟通不足，自去年12月回退版本后未充分回应GitHub上的大量用户反馈。还有用户提出了界面改进建议，如锁定输入框位置的功能需求。

comments.author: chrislloyd
comments.content: Hi! I work on TUI rendering for Claude Code. I know this has been a long-standing frustration — it's taken longer than any of us wanted.The good news: we shipped our differential renderer to everyone today. We rewrote our rendering system from scratch[1] and only ~1/3 of sessions see at least a flicker. Very, very few sessions see flickers in rapid succession which was so annoying before. Those numbers will keep dropping as people update.We've also been working upstream to add synchronized output / DEC mode 2026 support to environments where CC runs and have had patches accepted to VSCode's terminal[2]  and tmux[3]. Synchronized output totally eliminates flickering. As always, I recommend using Ghostty which has 2026 support and zero flicker.Happy to answer questions![1]: https://github.com/anthropics/claude-code/issues/769#issueco...[2]: https://github.com/xtermjs/xterm.js/pull/5453[3]: https://github.com/tmux/tmux/pull/4744
comments.content_cn:
大家好！我是负责Claude Code中TUI渲染的开发者。我知道这个问题长期以来一直令人困扰——解决时间比我们任何人预期的都要长。

好消息是：我们今天已经向所有用户推送了差异渲染器。我们从头重写了渲染系统[1]，现在只有约1/3的会话会出现至少一次闪烁。极少有会话会像之前那样出现连续快速闪烁的情况，那确实非常烦人。随着用户更新，这些数字还会持续下降。

我们还在上游环境中为Claude Code的运行环境增加了同步输出/DEC 2026模式支持，相关补丁已被VSCode终端[2]和tmux[3]采纳。同步输出功能能完全消除闪烁现象。一如既往，我推荐使用支持2026模式且零闪烁的Ghostty终端。

欢迎随时提问！

[1]: https://github.com/anthropics/claude-code/issues/769#issueco...
[2]: https://github.com/xtermjs/xterm.js/pull/5453
[3]: https://github.com/tmux/tmux/pull/4744

comments.author: chrislloyd
comments.content:
The communication is definitely on me! There honestly wasn't much new to say -I've been slowly ramping since early Jan just to be extra sure there's no regressions.  The main two perf. issues were:1. Since we no longer have <Static> components the app re-renders much more frequently with larger component trees. We were seeing unusual GC pauses because of having too much JSX... Better memoization has largely solved that.
2. The new renderer double buffers and blits similar cells between the front and back buffer to reduce memory pressure. However, we were still seeing large GC pauses from that so I ended up converting the screen buffer to packed TypedArrays.
comments.content_cn:
沟通的责任确实在我！老实说，这次没有太多新内容可讲——我从一月初就开始逐步推进，只是为了格外确保没有出现性能倒退。两个主要的性能问题是：
1. 由于我们不再使用组件，应用在渲染大型组件树时的重绘频率显著增加。我们曾因JSX过多而观察到异常的垃圾回收暂停……通过改进记忆化机制，这个问题已基本解决。
2. 新渲染器采用双缓冲机制，并通过在前后缓冲区之间复制相似单元格来降低内存压力。但此前我们仍因此出现较长的垃圾回收暂停，最终我将屏幕缓冲区转换为紧凑类型数组解决了该问题。

posts.title: Miami, your Waymo ride is ready
posts.author: ChrisArchitect
posts.title_cn: 迈阿密，您的Waymo自动驾驶出租车已就位
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕Waymo自动驾驶出租车服务扩展至迈阿密这一核心话题展开。社区普遍对自动驾驶技术的城市应用前景感到兴奋，认为其可能改变城市交通格局、减少停车空间需求，并带来新颖的乘坐体验。有用户分享在凤凰城的积极体验，认为Waymo提供了更私密、 futuristic 的出行选择。

主要争议点集中在经济影响与定价策略上。有用户指出，Waymo可能将大量收入转移出服务城市，影响本地经济循环，这与Uber/Lyft部分资金留存本地形成对比。在价格方面，尽管服务受好评，但不少用户质疑其定价与网约车相当甚至更高。有人认为，作为自动驾驶服务，其成本应显著更低以驱动市场变革；也有用户怀疑Waymo是否因难以盈利或出于利润考量而维持高价。此外，安全责任归属（如事故医疗费用）也被提及为潜在顾虑。

comments.author: treis
comments.content: We got these in Atlanta.  I haven't had the chance to ride yet but watching them it's pretty clear that they're legit.I think we're on the cusp of something that will change the landscape of our cities.  It's going to revolutionize getting around and take a chunk out of the land dedicated to parking.
comments.content_cn: 我们在亚特兰大看到了这些。我还没机会亲自体验，但观察下来很明显它们是货真价实的。我认为我们正处在改变城市面貌的变革边缘。这将彻底革新出行方式，并大幅减少用于停车的土地空间。

comments.author: melling
comments.content: I’m going to Miami next week.  Time for my first WayMo ride.
comments.content_cn: 下周我要去迈阿密，是时候体验我的第一次WayMo乘车了。

comments.content: The competition is growing.
comments.content_cn: 竞争日益激烈。

comments.author: nerdsniper
comments.content: It will also funnel large amounts of revenue out of every city into s/SF/Bay Area. Currently around 35% of the money spent on Uber/Lyft stays in the local economy. Waymo in SF still employs a large number of highly paid engineers who are paid the money which used to move through SF via Uber/Lyft. And those SF engineers spend a decent chunk of it locally on food, art, entertainment, and various other services - so it has (somewhat) less of an effect on the city's overall economy/total employment.Waymo in Miami won't be locally re-spending nearly as much of Miami's money as Uber/Lyft did. Significantly more of it will be removed from Miami with each ride. This might be even more pronounced for cities like Houston, which don't attract tourism from Waymo staff.
comments.content_cn: 这还将导致大量收入从每个城市流向旧金山/湾区。目前优步和Lyft约35%的消费资金留在了当地经济中。旧金山的Waymo仍然雇佣了大量高薪工程师，他们的薪酬原本是通过优步和Lyft在旧金山流动的资金。这些旧金山工程师在当地将相当一部分收入用于餐饮、艺术、娱乐及其他各种服务——因此对城市整体经济和总就业的影响（在一定程度上）较小。迈阿密的Waymo不会像优步和Lyft那样将迈阿密的资金大量重新投入本地消费。每次乘车服务都会有更多资金从迈阿密流出。对于休斯顿等无法吸引Waymo员工旅游的城市，这种效应可能更为显著。

comments.author: nthdesign
comments.content: I was at a conference in Phoenix in November and took seven Waymo trips during my stay. Four of those were fairly long (20-minute) trips. I preferred Waymo to the Uber/Lyft experience because it felt private. It was just me and my colleagues in the car, no strangers. It also felt futuristic and novel, which I'm sure will wear off. We experienced no weird or erratic driving, with one minor exception... Waymo always followed the speed limit. On a major road where the speed limit was 40mph, other cars were zipping around us at 55mph+. And, one parking lot had 5mph speed limit signs posted. As you can imagine, Waymo was the slowest vehicle in that parking lot by a wide margin.
comments.content_cn: 十一月我在凤凰城参加一场会议，期间乘坐了七次Waymo。其中四次行程相当长（约20分钟）。相比Uber/Lyft，我更喜欢Waymo，因为它提供了私密感——车里只有我和同事，没有陌生人。这种体验还充满未来感和新奇感，虽然我知道这种感觉迟早会淡化。除了一次微小例外，我们没遇到任何怪异或突兀的驾驶行为……Waymo始终严格遵守限速。在一条限速40英里/小时的主干道上，其他车辆都以55英里/小时以上的速度从我们旁边飞驰而过。另外，某个停车场明确标着5英里/小时的限速标志。可想而知，Waymo在那个停车场里成了速度最慢的车辆，而且慢得多。

comments.author: icyfox
comments.content: Waymo is such an interesting case study. For most other ~AI deployments you have strong public reaction to the proliferation of slop, non-human failure modes, cost cutting at the expense of quality, etc. But I haven't met a single person who doesn't like the experience of Waymo. They ended up cracking the code on what I suspect people really want:- consistent car quality- safety of the drive (conservative driving and potential fear of drivers)- no randomly chatty driverAll of those feel like a breath of fresh air especially when stacked up against the current state of Uber & Lyft rides. So a single trip adds one more leg.It might reduce the need for parking... potentially. But there will still need to be a certain amount of time dedicated to charging for these cars that requires parking.If private car ownership continues increasing in cost, and households become increasingly cost burdened (transportation is already the second highest cost for households), then I wonder how this will impact demand for housing in areas dependent on cars.Curious on the outcomes here. I think the best thing we can do for city transportation is increasing the number of viable transportation options. Waymo is one option amongst the options dependent on roads, but walking, biking, and transit should still be a priority so that we maintain competition amongst transportation modes.

posts.title: Show HN: Sweep, Open-weights 1.5B model for next-edit autocomplete
posts.content: Hey HN, we trained and open-sourced a 1.5B model that predicts your next edits, similar to Cursor. You can download the weights here (https://huggingface.co/sweepai/sweep-next-edit-1.5b) or try it in our JetBrains plugin (https://plugins.jetbrains.com/plugin/26860-sweep-ai-autocomp...).Next-edit autocomplete differs from standard autocomplete by using your recent edits as context when predicting completions. The model is small enough to run locally while outperforming models 4x its size on both speed and accuracy.We tested against Mercury (Inception), Zeta (Zed), and Instinct (Continue) across five benchmarks: next-edit above/below cursor, tab-to-jump for distant changes, standard FIM, and noisiness. We found exact-match accuracy correlates best with real usability because code is fairly precise and the solution space is small.Prompt format turned out to matter more than we expected. We ran a genetic algorithm over 30+ diff formats and found simple `original`/`updated` blocks beat unified diffs. The verbose format is just easier for smaller models to understand.Training was SFT on ~100k examples from permissively-licensed repos (4hrs on 8xH100), then RL for 2000 steps with tree-sitter parse checking and size regularization. The RL step fixes edge cases SFT can’t like, generating code that doesn’t parse or overly verbose outputs.We're open-sourcing the weights so the community can build fast, privacy-preserving autocomplete for any editor. If you're building for VSCode, Neovim, or something else, we'd love to see what you make with it!
posts.author: williamzeng0
posts.title_cn: "Show HN: Sweep，用于下一编辑自动补全的开源权重1.5B模型"
posts.content_cn:
嘿，HN的朋友们，我们训练并开源了一个15亿参数的模型，它能预测你的下一次编辑，类似于Cursor的功能。你可以在这里下载权重（https://huggingface.co/sweepai/sweep-next-edit-1.5b），或者通过我们的JetBrains插件试用（https://plugins.jetbrains.com/plugin/26860-sweep-ai-autocomp...）。  
“下一次编辑”自动补全与标准自动补全的不同之处在于，它在预测补全内容时会使用你最近的编辑作为上下文。这个模型足够小，可以在本地运行，同时在速度和准确性上都优于比它大四倍的模型。  
我们在五个基准测试中对比了Mercury（Inception）、Zeta（Zed）和Instinct（Continue），包括：光标上方/下方的下一次编辑、远距离更改的Tab跳转、标准FIM以及噪声测试。我们发现，精确匹配的准确率与实际可用性最为相关，因为代码相当精确，解决方案空间较小。  
提示格式的重要性超出了我们的预期。我们对30多种差异格式运行了遗传算法，发现简单的“原始”/“更新”块优于统一格式……
posts.abstract:
该HackerNews帖子讨论了Sweep团队开源的一个15亿参数模型，用于基于近期编辑内容预测下一步代码编辑的自动补全工具。核心话题围绕这一轻量级本地运行模型的开源发布及其在开发效率上的应用潜力。

社区普遍对小型高效模型的发展表示兴奋。许多用户赞赏其开源性质，认为这降低了使用门槛，并推动了可在个人硬件上运行的高性能模型进步。有人认为此类工具能显著提升编写模板代码时的效率，甚至比某些大型AI编程助手更实用；也有用户指出，离线运行能力是关键优势，尤其适合VRAM有限的开发者。

主要争议点集中在模型透明度上。有用户质疑仅公开权重而缺乏训练数据细节是否算真正的“开源”，认为“开放权重”可能掩盖了训练过程的不透明性。此外，关于插件实际使用体验存在不同反馈：部分用户顺利集成并给予好评，也有用户对JetBrains插件是否需要云端登录及是否真正支持本地运行表示困惑。讨论中还提到，有用户希望进一步厘清该模型与填充中间代码（FIM）模型的具体区别与应用场景。

Also, if the boilerplate code is configuration, its good to see exactly what the configuration is when trying to grok how some code works.You bring up a good point with snippets though, and I wonder if that would be good information to feed into the LLM for autocomplete. That snippet is helpful if you want to write on condition at a time, but say you have a dozen conditions if statements to write with that snippet. After writing one, the LLM could generate a suggestion for the other 11 conditions using that same snippet, while also taking into consideration the different types of values and what you might be checking against.As for RAM/processing, you're not wrong there, but with specialized models, specialized hardware, and improvements in model design, the number of people working under such restricted environments where they are concerned about resource use will decrease over time, and the utility of these tools will increase. Sure a lower-tech solution works just fine, and it'll continue to work fine, but at some point the higher-tech solution will have similar levels of friction and resource use for much better utility.

posts.title: From stealth blackout to whitelisting: Inside the Iranian shutdown
posts.author: oavioklein
posts.title_cn: 从隐秘断网到白名单：伊朗网络关闭内幕
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕伊朗政府实施的互联网管控措施展开，核心话题是伊朗从全面断网转向“白名单”系统的策略及其影响。讨论中提到，伊朗政府正在构建国家内部网络，通过白名单机制选择性允许特定用户和服务访问互联网，同时限制普通民众的连接。

有人认为这种措施显示了政府的技术性管控能力，能够通过保留IPv4路由实现选择性访问，避免国家完全失联；也有用户指出，这种做法实质上加剧了信息不平等，仅让技术人员或特定群体得以通过安全IP接入外部服务（如Google Colab），而多数人被隔绝。部分用户强调，伊朗国内已发展出相对自主的互联网基础设施，减少了对外部依赖。

讨论中存在分歧：一方认为政府的策略是经过精密设计的“扰动-观察”循环，可能获得他国技术支持；另一方则批评互联网封锁掩盖了实地新闻报道的缺失，使外界难以了解真实情况。共识在于，互联网管控已成为伊朗社会动荡中的关键弱点，但民众在断网期间仍尝试寻找替代沟通方式。

posts.title: ISO PDF spec is getting Brotli – ~20 % smaller documents with no quality loss
posts.author: whizzx
posts.title_cn: ISO PDF规范将引入Brotli压缩——文档体积缩减约20%且无损质量
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕ISO PDF规范将引入Brotli压缩算法展开，核心争议在于此举是否违背PDF长期坚持的向后兼容原则。多数用户质疑选择Brotli而非性能更优的Zstandard（zstd）的合理性，认为未搭配定制字典的Brotli在PDF这类多次读取格式中效益有限。有用户指出，仅20%的压缩率提升不值得以破坏兼容性为代价，且网络与存储发展将弱化此优势。同时，讨论中提到部分用户对PDF本身的发展方向表示不满，认为其因动态XFA等功能已偏离稳定文档格式的定位。值得注意的是，有观点肯定PDF因严格兼容性而成为通用格式的价值，认为缓慢演进具有合理性。整体而言，社区虽认可压缩技术升级的初衷，但对具体实施方案存在明显分歧。

comments.content_cn: 这篇文章里有些真正的认知失调……“PDF协会遵循一个严格原则——任何新功能都必须与现有阅读器无缝协作”，紧接着在同一段落就介绍了压缩功能作为破坏性变更。这一切都是为了brotli……对于PDF这种需要频繁读取的格式，zstd的解压速度其实是更合适的选择。

comments.content: BTW I've looked into custom dictionaries before for similar use cases and I suspect it would only offer like a 1% improvement or so for PDFs -- still good, but not a massive difference maker.  The issue is that PDFs, like web pages, are incredibly repetitive in terms of their tags/structure.  As such the custom dictionary only helps if the doc is really small, otherwise because of the repetitive nature, the self-inferred dictionary will resemble the custom dictionary after just a few blocks of PDF content.The sole exception is if they are restarting the brotli stream for each page, and they are not sharing a dictionary, custom or inferred across the whole doc.  Then the dictionary will have to be re-inferred on each page, and then a shared custom dictionary would make more sense.

The answers to https://stackoverflow.com/q/429987/5223757 discuss a wide variety of tools for producing (and seeking into) such files, which can be read normally by tools not familiar with the conventions in use.

posts.title: Ubisoft cancels six games including Prince of Persia and closes studios
posts.author: piqufoh
posts.title_cn: 育碧取消包括《波斯王子》在内的六款游戏并关闭工作室
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕育碧取消包括《波斯王子》在内的六款游戏并关闭工作室的新闻展开。核心话题聚焦于育碧等大型游戏公司近年来的决策困境及其对行业的影响。

社区观点呈现明显分歧。许多用户批评育碧等大公司过度追求公式化开放世界和微交易，扼杀了创意与玩家体验。有前员工指出，总部过度干预导致优秀工作室难以发挥；也有用户认为，公司一边以成本上涨为由裁员，一边鼓吹AI替代人力，实则是轻视人才价值。部分玩家对《雷曼》《波斯王子》等经典IP被搁置表示失望。

讨论中形成一定共识：大型企业为追求可复制的盈利模式，往往牺牲创意与员工权益，最终损害作品质量和玩家信任。同时，社区也期待独立工作室能借此机会吸纳人才，带来更多创新作品。

Because of that management pressure, a lot of the top talent just decided to leave.Ubisoft leadership has made so many bad moves lately. They wasted huge amounts of money on NFT/crypto stuff that nobody wanted. Then they made that awful comment about how "gamers should get used to not owning their games." Even if that’s where the industry is heading, saying it out loud to your own customers is just crazy. It’s like they don't understand their own audience anymore.

comments.author: jmyeet
comments.content: I find almost all modern content producers to be a depressing business, fundamentally incompatible with being a large corporation. This includes movies, TV and video games.The problem is the large corporation wants to remove creativity from the process. They want a repeatable formula that they can scale and infinitely reproduce.The wet dream for the modern AAA studio is a "game" like FIFA that has annual releases and loot boxes to gamble on to get better pixels. Call of Duty and similar games are the next best because it's user-generated content ("UGC"). They still have to invest to create maps, which they don't like doing. But you still have micro-transactions for skins so that's good (for them).I played Assassin's Creed Odyssey a lot. Some people don't like it because it's too CRPG. That's why I liked it. They paid a lot of attention to the environment. I've heard of teachers using it to portray ancient Greece.They managed this even though it was a little formulaic. I suspect that any future AC releases will be even more formulaic.The one exception to this "large game studio = bad" rule had been Rockstar. The various GTA3 titles and GTA4 were widely renowned because of their social commentary and wit, as well as being groundbreaking (at the time) for open world games.But GTA5 was a turning point for me. Yes it was a sprawling, beautiful environment but the writing was complete ass. It had none of the intelligence and insight of earlier titles. The characters were awful. But Rockstar seemingly didn't care because they're discovered the GTA Online money faucet, something I don't care about at all.I really wonder if GTA6 will be beautiful but soulless. It coudl go either way. RDR2 was released after GTA5, after all.These big studios really do have a habit of killing successful franchises or simply sucking the life out of them. There are few bigger fumbles than the EA SimCity fiasco. I guess you can say Civilization has maintained... something. But honestly I haven't really felt compelled to play the franchise much since Civ4.I do miss the days when games were games not just loot box slot machines with annual reskins.
comments.content_cn:
我发现几乎所有现代内容创作者都陷入一种令人沮丧的商业模式，这种模式从根本上与大型企业的运作逻辑相悖。这包括电影、电视剧和电子游戏行业。问题在于大型企业总试图剔除创作过程中的创造性元素，他们追求的是可复制的流水线公式，以便实现规模化生产和无限复制。

当代3A游戏工作室的理想模板是像《FIFA》这样的"游戏"——每年推出新版本，并设置开箱机制让玩家为虚拟数据赌博。《使命召唤》这类游戏次之，因其依赖用户生成内容。虽然仍需投入资源制作地图（这是他们不情愿的），但通过皮肤微交易仍能获利（对他们而言）。

我曾深度游玩《刺客信条：奥德赛》。部分玩家因其过于角色扮演化而不满，而这正是我欣赏之处。开发团队对环境细节的雕琢令人惊叹，甚至听闻有教师用它来展示古希腊风貌。尽管存在模式化痕迹，他们仍实现了这种品质。我推测未来该系列作品将更加套路化。

此前唯一打破"大厂必出庸作"定律的是Rockstar。《GTA3》系列与《GTA4》因其社会批判的锋芒与开创性的开放世界设计（在当时）广受赞誉。但《GTA5》对我而言是个转折点——虽然构建了宏大的精美世界，剧本却拙劣不堪，既缺乏早期作品的智慧洞察，人物塑造也糟糕透顶。不过……

The process you describe, of porting the code and polishing the visuals, is for a "remaster". Ubisoft's now-cancelled Sands of Time project was described as a "remake" [1], which generally is a bigger project that keeps the same characters and story beats as the original, but revises the art and gameplay almost as if it were a sequel.I agree that remakes sound straightforward and it's baffling that Ubisoft couldn't get this one out the door: there are rumors that even before its announcement in 2020, the Sands of Time remake had been started, scrapped, and restarted. But even Nightdive Studios, a perennial remaster maker, struggled for many years with their System Shock remake [2] so it must be harder than it sounds.I'd love to hear the inside story from folks who've worked on remakes (both released and cancelled) about why they aren't as straightforward as fans expect. Nightdive recently discussed the emotional toll from dealing with angry fans [3] but I haven't seen any interviews discussing the development challenges.[1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_game_remake#Remaster

posts.title: Show HN: Rails UI
posts.author: justalever
posts.title_cn: "Show HN: Rails UI"
posts.abstract: 该HackerNews帖子讨论了新发布的Rails UI框架。核心话题围绕该UI工具的价值、定价、设计实现及技术问题展开。社区观点多元：有人认为其定价过高，指出可用低价主题配合AI工具实现类似效果；也有用户指出其在色彩对比度、移动端体验及Safari兼容性等方面存在技术缺陷。讨论中提到，部分用户欣赏其对Rails生态的贡献及设计美感，但担忧在实际公司环境中，UI框架可能引发设计师与产品负责人的权限冲突。普遍共识是，该工具在快速原型开发中具有效率优势，但目前版本在细节体验和跨平台稳定性上仍需改进。分歧主要体现在价格合理性及设计自主性上，一方认为高价阻碍采用，另一方则认可其人工设计价值。

posts.title: Doctors in Brazil using tilapia fish skin to treat burn victims (2017)
posts.author: kaycebasques
posts.title_cn: 巴西医生采用罗非鱼皮治疗烧伤患者（2017）
posts.abstract:
该帖子讨论了巴西医生使用罗非鱼皮治疗烧伤患者的技术。核心话题围绕这种生物敷料的实际应用与潜在价值展开。

社区讨论中，有人认为这是一种成熟有效的技术，不仅巴西在使用，冰岛的兽医也用它处理动物伤口，且效果显著。也有用户指出，类似利用天然材料（如蜂蜜敷料、发霉面包）处理伤口的方法在历史上早有记载，中国农村也有使用鱼皮、土豆皮等传统经验。讨论中提到，这种方法的优势在于无需每日更换、保湿性好、能减少抗生素使用且成本低廉。

主要争议点在于技术的新颖性，部分用户认为这已是成熟技术，标题应标注2017年。共识在于普遍认同天然材料在伤口护理中的实用性和经济性，尤其适用于医疗资源有限的场景。分歧则体现在对其创新性的评价，以及是否应对不同地区（如兽医与人类医疗）的应用进行更深入的比较研究。

comments.author: osmano807
comments.content: In my hospital we have ample experience with another technique using polypropylene sheets for defect coverage, popularized in Brazil orthopedics as "Figueiredo's technique", which is in practice an extension of common techinques for temporary closure of abdominal wall ("Bogota's bag").We put a transparent polypropylene sheet as skin replacement, suture it directly to the skin. We can monitor the wound and its secretions, can cover exposed tendons and bones without immediate doing microsurgical flaps. For example, we can monitor the second intention skin closure with reduced infection and analgesics use, sometimes without needing a graft at all.
comments.content_cn: 在我院，我们对另一种使用聚丙烯片覆盖缺损的技术拥有丰富经验，该技术在巴西骨科界被称为"菲格雷多技术"，实际上是腹部壁临时闭合常用技术（"波哥大袋"）的延伸应用。我们将透明聚丙烯片作为皮肤替代物，直接缝合到皮肤上。这样既能观察伤口及分泌物情况，又能覆盖暴露的肌腱和骨骼而无需立即进行显微外科皮瓣手术。例如，我们可以通过二期愈合监测皮肤闭合过程，既降低了感染风险又减少了镇痛剂使用，有时甚至完全不需要植皮。

posts.title: 40M Americans Live Alone, 29% of households
posts.author: helsinkiandrew
posts.title_cn: 4000万美国人独居，占家庭总数的29%
posts.abstract:
该HackerNews帖子围绕“美国4000万人独居，占家庭户29%”的数据展开讨论。核心话题是独居现象的社会成因与影响，以及这是否构成问题。

有人认为独居是个人自由选择，29%的比例在发达国家中并不算高，且是持续三十多年的趋势，无需过度解读。也有用户指出，独居可能加剧住房危机和孤独感，若更多人选择合租，既能减轻经济压力又能扩大社交圈。讨论中提到，年轻人为节省开支而合租是常见经历，虽可能遇到糟糕室友，但也能培养人际处理能力。部分用户将独居现象归因于社会过度个人主义，或怀疑商业利益推动（如促使更多人独立支付各类账单）。还有观点认为，住房危机部分源于老年人“就地养老”占据过大空间，造成资源利用低效。

社区共识较少，主要分歧在于：一方视独居为正常社会现象，另一方则担忧其带来的经济与社会成本。

That’s fine. But it’s a weird default for early in one’s career. posts.author: personjerry
posts.title_cn: Capital One以51.5亿美元收购Brex
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕Capital One以51.5亿美元收购金融科技公司Brex的新闻展开。核心话题聚焦于此次收购的估值合理性、Brex的发展轨迹及其与竞争对手的比较。

多数用户注意到Brex在2021年以123亿美元估值融资后，此次收购价大幅缩水，认为这对后期投资者和员工可能造成损失。有观点指出，尽管早期投资者因清算优先权而未亏损，但2021年后入职的员工很可能面临股权价值低于行权价的困境。

讨论中出现了不同评价：有人认为收购对已融资17亿美元的Brex而言仍是良好退出，至少避免了更差结局；也有用户指出Brex虽早期领先，但后期被竞争对手Ramp在开发速度和AI转型上反超，这可能是其被迫出售的原因之一。此外，有用户提及Brex曾因创业公司缺乏风投资金而拒绝服务，反映了其业务策略的争议性。

整体上，社区普遍认为这是估值泡沫破裂的典型案例，但对交易本身是否划算存在分歧。

posts.title: Beowulf's opening "What" is no interjection (2013)
posts.author: gsf_emergency_6
posts.title_cn: 《贝奥武夫》开篇的"What"并非感叹词（2013）
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕《贝奥武夫》开篇词"Hwæt"的翻译争议展开。有用户指出，该词的翻译在学术界已争论数百年，托尔金等学者均有不同解读，因此新观点未必能颠覆传统。有人认为研究者提出的"应被未来译本考虑"的说法显得自大且带有幽默感。讨论中提到，Maria Dahvana Headley的译本将其译为"Bro!"，体现了现代诠释的多样性。也有用户指出，古英语中的"Hwæt"可能类似波斯史诗《玛斯纳维》开篇的"倾听"，或是英语"what ho"的起源。对于翻译分歧的实际意义，部分用户质疑其是否真正影响理解，而更多人认同翻译差异反映了学术诠释的多元性。共识在于，《贝奥武夫》的翻译始终是开放性的学术对话，不同译本各有价值。

comments.author: tracerbulletx
comments.content: Beowulf translation is a whole academic field, the translation has been debated ad nauseum for 100s of years, Tolkien had his own translation and opinion, which differed from others. One additional scholar adding his own interpretation doesn't necessarily overturn anything. There is not enough detail in this article to know how compelling the case is or what the counter arguments would be.
comments.content_cn: 《贝奥武夫》的翻译是一个完整的学术领域，相关译本的争论已持续数百年，托尔金本人也有其独特的译本和见解，与其他学者观点相异。一位学者提出新的解读未必能颠覆现有研究。本文提供的细节有限，难以判断其论证是否有力，亦无法得知可能存在的反驳观点。

comments.author: spyrja
comments.content: I agree with Dr. Walkden here. While it was used as an interjection at times (just as it is today when someone exclaims, "What?!") in the context of the opening line of Beowulf "hwæt" is more likely being used to reformulate a statement in order to convey a sense of emphasis. An example in modern English would be something like, rather than saying "That was a gorgeous sunset!", one says "What a gorgeous sunset that was!". (Notice that the verb has now moved to the end of the sentence. In fact if you look at the last word of the line in question, we have the verb "fremedon" which means "performed", so indeed the placement of "what" at the beginning of the line facilitates the restructuring of the sentence in such a way that makes it "sounds right".)

comments.author: pcrh
comments.content: It took me a few minutes to track down the original source of this. It is a paper by Dr George Walkden published in 2013 called "The status of hwæt in Old English" You can access the pdf from the link below [0].The abstract reads:>It is commonly held that Old English hwæt, well known within Anglo-Saxon studies as the first word of the epic poem Beowulf, can be ‘used as an adv[erb]. or interj[ection]. Why, what! ah!’ (Bosworth & Toller 1898, s.v. hwæt, 1) as well as the neuter singular of the interrogative pronoun hwa ̄ ‘what’. In this article I challenge the view that hwæt can have the status of an interjection (i.e. be outside the clause that it precedes). I present evidence from Old English and Old Saxon constituent order which suggests that hwæt is unlikely to be extra-clausal. Data is drawn from the Old English Bede, Ælfric’s Lives of Saints and the Old Saxon Heliand. In all three texts the verb appears later in clauses preceded by hwæt than is normal in root clauses (Fisher’s exact test, p < 0.0001 in both cases). If hwæt affects the constituent order of the clause it precedes, then it cannot be truly clause- external. I argue that it is hwæt combined with the clause that follows it that delivers the interpretive effect of exclamation, not hwæt alone. The structure of hwæt-clauses is sketched following Rett’s (2008) analysis of exclamatives. I conclude that Old English hwæt (as well as its Old Saxon cognate) was not an interjection but an underspecified wh-pronoun introducing an exclamative clause.[0] https://kops.uni-konstanz.de/server/api/core/bitstreams/413d...
comments.content_cn:
我花了几分钟才找到这个问题的原始出处。这是乔治·沃克登博士于2013年发表的论文，题为《古英语中hwæt的语法地位》。您可以通过以下链接[0]获取PDF文件。摘要如下：

>学界普遍认为，古英语词汇hwæt（作为史诗《贝奥武夫》的首词在盎格鲁-撒克逊研究领域广为人知）既可“作为副词或感叹词使用，意为‘为何！什么！啊！’”（Bosworth & Toller 1898, hwæt词条），也可作为疑问代词hwā“什么”的中性单数形式。本文对“hwæt具有感叹词地位（即独立于其引导的从句之外）”的观点提出质疑。通过分析古英语和古撒克逊语的成分语序，我发现hwæt不太可能属于句外成分。研究数据取自《古英语比德译本》《埃尔弗里克圣徒传》及古撒克逊语《救世主》文本。在这三部文献中，hwæt引导的从句里动词出现位置均晚于常规主句（费希尔精确检验显示两种情况p值均<0.0001）。若hwæt能影响其后从句的成分语序，则其本质上不可能完全独立于从句。我认为正是hwæt与其后续从句共同作用产生了感叹的诠释效果，而非hwæt单独作用。本文参照雷特（2008）对感叹句的分析方法勾勒了hwæt从句的结构框架。最终得出结论：古英语hwæt（及其古撒克逊语同源词）并非感叹词，而是一种未充分限定的疑问代词……

comments.author: spyrja
comments.content: Not really. It does however help drive home the point that such interjections were unlikely to be used by speakers of Nordic languages in order to begin a tale. (On the other hand in Latin and Celtic traditions, interjections were widely used in story-telling, eg. "Ecce!" and "Féach!" respectively). Old English speakers would have been more inclined to used interjections in a responsive context. For example, to the statement "The boat is taking on water!", one might respond "How?!". But to begin a conversation with an interjection, that just isn't consistent with what we see in any of the speech patterns found in languages which developed from Old Norse.
comments.content_cn: 并非如此。但这确实有助于阐明一个观点：北欧语言的使用者不太可能使用这类感叹词来开启一个故事。（另一方面，在拉丁和凯尔特传统中，感叹词在叙事中被广泛使用，例如分别用"Ecce!"和"Féach!"）。古英语使用者更倾向于在回应情境中使用感叹词。例如，对于"船正在进水！"这样的陈述，可能会回应"怎么会？！"。但用感叹词开始对话，这与我们从古诺尔斯语发展而来的任何语言中的说话模式都不相符。

comments.content: I had a history professor who would often use a similar preamble phrase. His was "And SO IT IS that we see that..."It worked to get our attention partly because of the time it took to say all that, and partly because it was so idiosyncratic that it sorta became a running joke.I remember one session in particular.This was a summer class, and as such each class session was around 2 hours long. The professor would typically give us (and himself) a 10-minute break in the middle of the class, and generally if you hung around the room, he'd strike up a more casual conversation in the room.This was also not long after Michael Jackson died. The conversation got onto him and his life and his mixed legacy of scandal, went on for a while, and somehow made its way to one student observing that (and I quote): "he lived the American dream – he started out as a poor black boy and grew up to be a rich white man."The room sorta hung in uneasy suspense at how the professor would respond."...and SO IT IS that we see that the Mongol conquest...", he said, launching noticeably-abruptly (and with a bit of a knowing grin) back into the course material.He was generally a good-natured dude like that. His voice sounded a little unusual, and I guess some students thought he sounded like Kermit the Frog. He came back into the room after a bathroom break once to find someone had drawn Kermit on the whiteboard behind where he usually stood when speaking. He saw it, stopped, visibly pondered what to do with it, and drew a speech bubble from Kermit saying something like "the Silk Road" (or whatever it was were about to cover; it's been quite a few years and I don't remember the specific topic).

我曾有位历史教授，总爱用类似的开场白。他的口头禅是：“由此我们可见……”这句话之所以能吸引我们的注意力，一方面是因为说完它需要点时间，另一方面则是因为这说法太有个人特色，几乎成了我们私下流传的梗。

我尤其记得某次课上的情景。那是门暑期课程，每节课大约两小时。教授通常会在课间给我们（也给自己）十分钟休息时间，如果你留在教室里，他往往会和大家闲聊几句。

那时迈克尔·杰克逊刚去世不久。聊天话题转到了他的人生以及他毁誉参半的传奇经历。讨论持续了一阵子，后来有位同学突然说道（我直接引用原话）：“他实现了美国梦——从一个贫穷的黑人男孩，最终变成了富有的白人。”

教室里顿时弥漫着不安的沉默，大家都等着看教授如何回应。

“……由此我们可见，蒙古帝国的征服……”他开口说道，明显突兀地切回了课程内容（嘴角还挂着一丝了然的微笑）。

他平时就是这样性情温和的人。他的嗓音有点特别，我猜有些学生觉得他说话像青蛙科米。有次他课间去洗手间回来，发现有人在他平时讲课站的白板位置画了只科米蛙。他看到后停下脚步，明显在思考该怎么处理……

comments.author: gjm11
comments.content: Same purpose, different grammatical structure.Heaney's famous translation begins "So. The Spear-Danes ..." with that "So" being an interjection, a thing that could in principle stand on its own. (You might say "So." and wait for everyone to settle down and start listening.) Even more so with things like "Yo!" or "What ho!" or "Bro!" or "Lo!". (Curious how all the options seem to end in -o.)This is more like "So, the Spear-Danes ..." where the initial "So" has roughly the same purpose of rhetorical throat-clearing and attention-getting, but now it's part of the sentence, as if it had been "As it turns out, the Spear-Danes ..." or "You might have heard that the Spear-Danes ...".I think the theory described in OP makes the function of "hwaet" a little different, though; not so much throat-clearing and attracting attention, as marking the sentence as exclamatory. A little like the "¡" that _begins_ an exclamation in Spanish.Of course a word can have more than one purpose, and it could be e.g. that "hwaet" marks a sentence as exclamatory and was chosen here because it functions as a way of drawing attention.
comments.content_cn: 相同目的，不同语法结构。希尼的著名译本以"那么。矛之丹麦人……"开篇，其中的"那么"是感叹词，原则上可独立存在。（你可能会先说"那么。"，等待众人安静下来开始倾听。）类似"哟！""喂！""兄弟！""看哪！"等表达更是如此。（有趣的是这些选项似乎都以-o结尾。）这更像是"那么，矛之丹麦人……"的句式，开头的"那么"大致起到修辞性清嗓和吸引注意的作用，但此时它已成为句子组成部分，仿佛在说"事实证明，矛之丹麦人……"或"你可能听说过矛之丹麦人……"。不过我认为原文描述的理论使"hwaet"的功能略有不同：与其说是清嗓吸引注意，不如说是标记句子为感叹性质。有点像西班牙语中开启感叹句的"¡"符号。当然一个词语可以承载多重功能，比如"hwaet"既能标记感叹句，在此处又被选用是因为它同时具备吸引注意力的作用。

comments.author: spyrja
comments.content: Nevertheless I do think it is safe to say that such interjections were used, at least on a day-to-day basis. (Bear in mind that relatively few Old English texts survive to this day and almost certainly not many were produced to begin with. Old Norse itself was for the most part a spoken language, unlike Latin for example, and its predecessor which developed in England only started to be written down because of external influences.) Point is, all of the Nordic languages employ interjections akin to "Ah!", "Oh!", "Why?!", "Indeed!", "How?!", etc. So there really isn't any reason to think that such things wouldn't exist in OE as well.
comments.content_cn: 尽管如此，我确实认为可以稳妥地说，这类感叹词至少在日常生活中是被使用的。（请记住，留存至今的古英语文本相对较少，而且最初产生的数量很可能就不多。古诺尔斯语本身主要是一种口语，不像拉丁语那样，其前身在英格兰的发展也是由于外部影响才开始被记录下来的。）关键在于，所有北欧语言都使用类似于“啊！”、“哦！”、“为什么？！”、“确实！”、“怎么？！”等感叹词。因此，实在没有理由认为古英语中不会存在这类表达。

posts.title: A Year of 3D Printing
posts.author: nindalf
posts.title_cn: "3D打印的一年"
posts.abstract:
该帖子围绕“一年3D打印经验”展开讨论，社区成员分享了个人实践中的偏好与观察。核心话题涉及3D打印的应用场景、技术体验及未来发展方向。

讨论中，用户们列举了多样的打印用途：有人认为数字日晷等创意模型最具吸引力，也有用户指出Gridfinity收纳系统等实用工具才是高频应用；部分用户专注于为其他打印机生产零件，还有用户欣赏网页中基于物理引擎的动态渲染效果。在技术体验上，有用户称赞Bambu A1 Mini等新型设备的易用性，对比了旧型号的调试困难；同时，关于模型边缘是否需进行圆角或倒角处理也存在不同设计倾向的争议。

对于金属3D打印的未来，社区普遍认为短期内难以进入家庭场景，但对商用服务的成本降低抱有期待。整体而言，讨论体现出3D打印既服务于创意表达，也广泛应用于实际工具制作，而设备可靠性与特定工艺细节仍是用户关注的重点。

comments.author: mysterydip
comments.content: In the past I've mostly printed intersting/amusing things from places like thingiverse. But this year I had a project I needed an enclosure for, and instead of using something off the shelf I decided to print my own.Being able to design, print, test, change, print again really made the potential of 3D printing shine for me. I must have went through a couple dozen iterations as the hardware choices solidified and I saw what worked and what didn't (like "oh, I actually can't reach that screw once these two pieces are put together"). It was a really rewarding experience and I'm looking forward to the next project.
comments.content_cn: 过去我主要从Thingiverse等网站打印些有趣的小物件。但今年有个项目需要外壳，我没有选择现成品，而是决定自己打印。设计、打印、测试、修改、再打印的整个过程让我真切体会到3D打印的潜力。随着硬件方案逐步确定，我反复修改了数十个版本，不断验证设计的可行性（比如发现"这两个部件组装后竟然无法拧到那颗螺丝"）。这段经历让我收获满满，已经开始期待下一个项目了。

comments.author: VladVladikoff
comments.content: I still have mixed emotions about 3D printing. I do love the idea of being able to print a part when I need it for something. But I do hate myself at the same time for creating more plastic junk. PLA is not really getting recycled, when it fails someone throws it in the trash and it goes to a landfill. Maybe some really diehard enthusiasts are ensuring all their failed prints and broken parts get properly chemically recycled, but I bet most don’t bother and just bin it.
comments.content_cn: 对于3D打印技术，我依然怀着复杂的心情。我确实喜欢能够在需要时打印出所需零件的想法。但同时我也讨厌自己制造了更多塑料垃圾。聚乳酸材料实际上并未得到有效回收，当打印失败时，人们往往将其扔进垃圾桶，最终进入填埋场。或许有些极度热衷的爱好者会确保将所有失败的打印件和损坏部件进行专业的化学回收，但我敢打赌大多数人并不会费心处理，只是直接丢弃。

comments.author: bborud
comments.content: I would encourage people who have never designed physical objects before to try to only print things they have designed themselves as an exercise. For perhaps a year or so.If you have never designed physical objects before it is really challenging at first.  The learning curve is pretty steep and, at least in my case, I discovered that I didn't have a mental language for thinking about functional 3D and mechanical design.  You also start to look more closely at the objects around you and think about what went into designing them.I started doing 3D design about a decade ago, when I got my first 3D printer. At first using free modeling in CAD and then later learning how to do constraint based and parametric designs in Fusion 360.  This felt slow and perhaps limiting at first, but when you get used to it, it will save you a lot of time later and allow you to make more useful designs that are much easier to evolve and vary.I think it took something like 4-5 years before I printed something someone else had designed.  Mostly because I used 3D printing to make custom parts for my own projects, but also in an effort to force myself to learn.  I know the learning curve was steep, but for some reason I have forgotten how much work it was to learn.Now there are so many useful designs, designed by people who are a lot better than me available everywhere that I do print a lot of things others have designed.  But I think learning to design things yourself is a really good opportunity to learn useful skills.For instance, I had never anticipated that I, a software engineer, would get paid, by an actual customer, to design parts for their projects.  Or even consult on physical design for someone doing product development.  I am by no means at the level where I'd put it front and center on a resume, but I can design, and to some degree, manufacture simple mechanical parts.(Along with 3D printing I've been doing some CNC at a very hobbyist level.  I would still say I am very much a beginner when it comes to machining metals, but it is really fun to see that you can make reasonably precise metal parts for real applications (car parts) at home in my garage with not that much effort. This weekend I'll be doing thread milling in aluminum for the first time on a part that requires M3 screws)
comments.content_cn:
我建议从未设计过实体物品的人，尝试只打印自己设计的作品作为练习，持续大约一年左右。对于初次接触实体设计的人来说，起步阶段确实充满挑战。学习曲线相当陡峭，至少就我个人而言，我发现自己在功能性三维和机械设计方面缺乏思维语言。你也会开始更仔细地观察周围的物品，思考它们的设计过程。

大约十年前，当我拥有第一台3D打印机时，我开始涉足三维设计。最初使用CAD进行自由建模，后来学习在Fusion 360中进行基于约束和参数化的设计。起初这感觉缓慢且可能有限制，但当你习惯后，它会为你节省大量时间，并使你能够创作出更有用、更易于改进和变化的设计。

我记得大概花了四到五年时间，才第一次打印别人设计的作品。主要是因为我用3D打印为自己项目定制零件，同时也为了强迫自己学习。我知道学习过程很艰难，但不知为何，我已经忘记了当时付出了多少努力。

如今，网上到处都是比我优秀得多的人设计的实用作品，我也经常打印他人的设计。但我认为，学会自己设计物品是一个极好的机会来……

comments.author: dgroshev
comments.content: I'd encourage people doing engineering/functional parts to also try ASA and PC(-CF). Both are pretty easy to print on enclosed printer like Prusa Core One, and they offer unique qualities that are impossible to achieve with PLA or PETG.Prusament PC Blend is insanely strong and stiff, I saw a 3mm PC bracket bending a high quality metal wood screw into an S-shape without breaking. PC-CF is much easier to print, looks great, and is stiffer still, even if a bit less strong. ASA looks great and is tougher than PC. Both creep less than PLA and PETG. Both shrug off 100C under load.
comments.content_cn: 我建议从事工程/功能部件制作的人士也尝试使用ASA和PC（-CF）材料。这两种材料在像Prusa Core One这样的封闭式打印机上都相当容易打印，并且它们具备PLA或PETG无法实现的独特性能。Prusament PC混合材料极其坚固且刚性极强，我曾见过一个3毫米厚的PC支架将高质量金属木螺丝弯成S形而自身未断裂。PC-CF打印起来更容易，外观出色，刚性更强，尽管强度稍逊。ASA外观精美且比PC更耐冲击。这两种材料在负载下的蠕变均小于PLA和PETG，且都能在100摄氏度下保持性能稳定。

comments.content: While they certainly correlate, downloads don't match print rates. Unless you got a ton of printers you are mostly doing one print at a time and each requires setup and cleanup, or possibly multiple attempts if there are difficult to print features.It can be multiple hours between prints because good prints take time. But you can spend 30 minutes browsing random peoples designs online and say "cool" and press download on 20 different designs that you only print 1 or 2 of ultimately.Also some designs look cool but the second you load your model up in a slicer you can see it is too finnicky or too long or expensive to print to be worth the effort.

comments.content: That's largely a myth.This review [1] cites the absolute highest amount of emitted styrene in the studies they are reviewing to be 113 μg/min. For comparison, the "work exposure limit (WEL) for styrene is currently 100 parts per million (ppm) averaged over an 8-hour day" [4].In other words, as long as you have some air exchange in the room, you'd be orders of magnitude away from the safe work exposure limit on styrene.It also makes sense, considering that it's a microscopic amount of molten plastic, whereas injection moulding factories work with vats of the stuff.[1]: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S135223102...[2]: https://teesing.com/en/tools/ppm-mg3-converter[3]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Styrene[4]: https://www.hse.gov.uk/plastics/faqs.htm

I find this concern a little odd because most people tend to do very little in their life to make a difference in ways that count way more than a couple kilograms
of PLA filament.Let’s take 1kg of filament, which is enough for multiple print projects depending on the size of the items.That is approximately the same weight of petrochemical material as 1/3 of a gallon of gas (making a bit of an assumption that the amount of processing per weight of both materials is roughly the same).Every time you drive 10 miles in a car that gets 30mpg it’s like you are burning an entire roll of filament.So the average American is using probably 1-4 rolls of filament just to get to work and back. The last time I bought a roll of filament was multiple months ago.I’m not singling you out, I am really just pointing out that humans are terrible at understanding the quantities of things and what things actually use a lot of material and create a lot of carbon emissions.This is especially true since cost is so detached from material use, waste, and carbon emissions.A gallon of gas is an order of magnitude cheaper than the equivalent weight of filament.Burning a bunch of BTUs of natural gas to make my house 4 degrees warmer and gain a trivial amount of additional comfort wastes a whole bunch of energy but costs me so little that I don’t even know what my gas bill is.It’s cheaper for me to replace most of my home appliances with brand new ones than hire a repair service.I can fly to Florida for $50 and burn 15 gallons of jet fuel.If I put more garbage out in my bin I’m not charged more. I can even put furniture and appliances out there and I am not charged more.These are all examples of waste and environmental impact where I don’t really see or feel the magnitude of them because our systems don’t show them.Anyway I know this is kind of a huge tangent of a discussion. But really, 3D printing is the least of your worries.

posts.title: SpaceX lowering orbits of 4,400 Starlink satellites for safety's sake
posts.author: thread_id
posts.title_cn: SpaceX为安全起见降低4400颗星链卫星轨道
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕SpaceX主动降低4400颗星链卫星轨道以提升太空安全性的举措展开。核心话题涉及卫星轨道调整的技术原理、太空碰撞风险及凯斯勒综合征的潜在威胁。有人认为此举能减少长期太空垃圾，因为较低轨道的碎片会更快衰减；也有用户指出，随着卫星数量激增，不同轨道卫星的轨迹交叉频率上升，即使非直角碰撞也可能引发连锁风险。讨论中提到，部分用户担忧太阳活动高峰期可能加剧轨道环境的不稳定性。技术层面，有解释称卫星通过向前喷射物质减速，从而降低轨道高度。尽管存在对大规模卫星网络可能成为军事冲突目标的猜测，但多数用户认为这种可能性较低。整体上，社区认同主动管理轨道安全是必要措施，但对如何平衡卫星部署规模与长期太空可持续性仍存在分歧。

comments.author: choeger

Or two satellites on different directions. That is going to be spectacular. Otoh, these kind of collisions are unlikely and should be manageable by just assigning certain shells (say 5km) for every possible direction and orientation.If two Starlink satellites collide that go roughly in the same direction, it's not exactly a huge problem.I think the biggest issue is to coordinate this and potentially disallow some excentric orbits.
comments.content_cn: 我认为需要指出的是，并非所有碰撞都具有同等的危险性。想象一下，一颗极地轨道卫星与一颗赤道轨道卫星相撞，或者两颗运行方向不同的卫星发生碰撞，那场面将会相当壮观。另一方面，这类碰撞发生的可能性较低，通过为每个可能的方向和轨道倾角分配特定的轨道层（比如5公里间隔）应该可以管理。如果两颗大致同向运行的星链卫星相撞，其实算不上什么大问题。我认为最大的挑战在于协调各方，并可能禁止某些偏心轨道。
